  197. I read all of the reviews on this before I made the purchase. The reviews made me a bit skeptical but I made the order anyway. When I opened the package, I read all of the instructions first. I can see that some of the reviewers did not read the instructions, judging from the comments. It works as advertised. I use the 2mm setting for a my buzz cut and I am very happy with it. I have not used any other settings. However, I have not yet been able to figure out how to make the trimmer (edger?)part of this device cut hair.
  198. Inside the box: Clipper, 2 attachment combs, charging adapter, cleaning brush, lubricating oil, and manual. Review: I bought this last summer because I thought it was an innovative hair clipper aimed at people who cut their own hair. However, tapering with this clipper is a little hard, so if you want to try styles other than a buzz cut, I would recommend getting the regular hair clippers from Andis or Oster. I have very thick and straight Asian hair, and this clipper did a good job of cutting through my hair, but I had to do several passes to get the hair nice and even. It takes a while to charge, around 14-16 hours, and lasts about 30-40 minutes on a single charge. It does not run with the adapter plugged in, so if it should run out of battery while cutting your hair, you're out of luck and will have to wait to at least partially charge it or resume the next day. I will note that it almost broke down on me once, when it would not turn on after a night of charging. I turned it on and off maybe 20 times before it started working. The attachments are easily adjustable with a scrolling wheel but they do not conform perfectly to certain areas of my head, like the sides. There are two attachments, one balding attachment which cuts from 1/32\\" (I do not know how long it can cut) and one adjustable guide comb which cuts from 1/8\\" to 1/2\\". The manual says that it can be washed under water but it says to lubricate it with the provided oil afterward. I recommend lubricating with oil before every haircut as with other clippers. Summary: Pros: -Easy, respectable self buzz cuts -Cordless -Easy adjustment of attachments -Easy to hold while cutting hair -Easy to maintain, just clean blades with supplied brush and lubricate Cons: -Mainly for buzz cuts. ades, crew cuts, etc -Cannot be operated while plugged in -When the battery dies, the whole clipper has to be replaced In conclusion, buy this if all you're looking for is a buzz cut. You can giveyourself a decent buzz cut in about 10 minutes. If you're looking to try different hair styles, invest in a clipper like the Andis Improved master or Oster Fast Feed clippers.
  199. As someone with no hair left on top, this works well for me. I read a bunch of reviews before I ordered it. Most concerning was the battery life. Mine seems to hold a charge just fine, no problem as of yet. For those with a full head of hair, I don't know if its for you. Unless you want to keep your hair really short. Since its already saved me about $30 at the barber (sorry George) It has paid for itself in time and money. It works for me. As of 3/7/15 The battery is holding a charge just fine. I've only charged it four times. This thing is awesome!
  200. I love it! cuts even and trims well. I have another simular product and this is by far the best. I may get another for gifts...
  201. As noted, by other reviewers, the battery recharging time is long. A light weight clipper with easy maneuverability. Worked fine, for Burr and Butch style self cuts, except in flat areas; like the areas directly behind and above the ears, and the sideburns areas. The trimmer does not have comb attachments, so it cannot be used to cut or trim the flat areas, to desired lengths. A separate clipper, with the appropriate size comb, is required to cut, and trim the flat areas. It is advisable to use a vacuum cleaner, to vacuum off the hair clippings, off the blades and device, instead of rinsing them off, under a faucet, as the owner's guide, mentions the clipper blades are lubed for life, if the oil is not rinsed off.
  202. I had concerns over reviews saying that the battery may not last, but figured that since haircuts cost me $17, it will save money if I only use it twice. Went to my barber one last (?) time and got a 1/4&#34; buzzcut. The product arrived in 5 days with super saver shipping. Everything was new and intact. Carefully read the manual and changed out the &#34;balding comb&#34; for adjustable comb guard. Have now used twice. It charged up well in 16 hours and ran for over 20 minutes. Unit cuts hair into tiny pieces, but as long as hair is already short, it cut evenly. Did not rinse under water, it was easy to brush out hair on blade after removing guard; can't see adnvantage in washing and having to re-oil it. Have only used twice, but this means I have already saved money! ***Feb., 2016 Sadly, it appears that Remington has discontinued this model and replaced it with one costing nearly 3X more. I have had my first SC100 now for over 5 years and use it an average of once per month. I occasionally still go to my barber to get cleaned up because this &#34;electrobarber&#34; does not do a very god job around my ears and the back of my neck. Because I was concerned about the reviewers reports of poor battery life, I purchased a second SC100 in April 2014. It is still in the box unused. I am sorry to see this model go, but if I ever need a new one, I am happy that Remington still offers a redesigned (and hopefully improved model). RIP SC-100.....

  209. Easy to use, gives a good clean cut

  211. When I first purchased the Short Cut Clippers, I thought they were one of the best ideas ever to get a close, balding type cut. The cut was great and the use was easy, much quicker than with my 15 year old corded Conair clippers, and they were a brand I trusted, Remington, the same brand as my 10 year old foil shaver. After several uses, it started to act as if the batteries were running down during the cut. They would turn on and right back off. I found that if I oiled the blades, they would run again for a while, and at least let me finish the cut. As time went by, they would always start the cut, but stop before I was done. Sometimes oiling would help, and other times, they would continue to start and stop over and over again. Having not kept the receipt and not being able to remember if I registered the product, I figured I would look into the problem myself. With the unit apart, I could not make it stop running. It did not appear to be a battery problem, but some kind of mechanical binding problem. I actually used it for several months with the outside case off, and it worked fine. After a couple more months of messing with it, and with it no longer charging, I pitched it in the trash and chalked it up to a defective one that got through the system. As I was looking through Amazon.com today for some sort of similar clippers, I ran across the Short Cut Clippers again, and found that almost everyone was experiencing the same problem that I had, though most thought of it as a weak battery problem. These clippers were a great idea poorly executed. With so many people complaining of similar problems, Remington should have some kind of recall or reimbursement for these clippers.
  212. It died after 1 use. It worked really well, then the battery stopped taking a charge and I can't run it on the power cord either. Of course I realized this after the 30 day Amazon warranty period.
  213. I thought this was the answer to my prayers for cutting my hair. The design matched my desire for something easy to use and intelligence. Instructions were informative and good.   214. I love this thing. Its very easy to use and works great. I experienced what seemed like a charging issue mentioned in several reviews and finally discovered that if you rinse the cutter in some water - what seemed like a charging issue goes away. Apparently the razor gets clogged up and rinsing it in water fixes the problem. I was convinced that my unit wasn't charging properly, so I read the directions. I rinsed it off when I thought it was near dead and it worked like new without re-charging. Try it!
  215. I bought this because the design looked ergo and convenient compared to a typical clipper. However, the \\"balding\\" comb doesn't come close to a real bald cut. This cuts more like a #1/2 or #1 on a standard clipper. Waste of money if you want something close to a shaved look. Buy the Wahl Balding Clipper. It's very close to a shave.
  216. I have been giving myself hair cuts for many years now. I am replacing a \\"classic\\" cutter with this. I keep my hair short and it is fine and thinning. So this cutter has no problem with cutting my hair.<br /><br />Pros - It gives a very nice and very clean and even looking cut. I really like the design and the comfort of using it. I also like that it is as simple as a \\"back and forth\\" motion and you really do get a nice results. The adjustable guard (length) system is great and the extendable trimmer works as you would expect.<br /><br />Cons - First off this bad boy is messy to use! It is much more messy than a \\"classic\\" style cutter. The back and forth action produces tons of small cut off pieces that rain down (as does a one way action). The other issue is that I used this on my son who has very thick and more than a normal persons share of hair. His hair was a little longer (like a couple of inches). This cutter could not handle the thickness and length. It was consistently clogging the cutter guides and was just not getting the job done. I had to get one of my classic cutters and cut his hair down to a length just longer than the length I wanted to end with. Once I cut off the \\"excess\\" hair then the cutter gave a very nice finished look. (again making a mess)<br /><br />I am not thrilled with it being a rechargeable as I would prefer a cord so I would not have to deal with what I know will be the eventual and certain battery failure as all rechargeables have.<br /><br />All and all I like the unit as it really does a nice job and is easy to use.
  217. Great buy. I like my hair very short. Almost bald. This does the job. Works best when your scalp is clean and dry.
  218. Works well, but battery recharge feature is short lived. Have bought 3 of them, only because they cut very well.

  220. So... I've been buzzing my head for a number of years now... I'm a clipper snob... Finding a clipper that does the job without sawing your head off is not always easy... There are plenty of cheaply made rechargeable clippers out there... Some of those cheaply made clippers are far from being cheap in price... I buzz my head once or twice a week... The last set of Whal clippers I purchased barely lasted 6 months... I can't remember the company that made the clippers I used before the Whal clippers but they lasted maybe 6 months as well... Anyway... I decided to order the Remington Short Cut Clippers despite a few bad reviews and I am very pleased so far... Now I cut with the balding guard on and set to the lowest setting... It appears that the Short Cut cuts shorter than other clippers I have used... I like that !! Easy to go longer if I want... The price of the Short Cut also surprised me... I hate to say this but I figured they could not be that good cause they were so much cheaper than other clippers... Funny thing is that the Short Cut looks like it would cost much more... My Whal clippers cost $60 or more dollars and looked cheaply made (Apparently they were cheaply made cause the plastic parts in the cutter head broke down after 6 months)... Anyway... So far I really like the short cut... The pop up trimmer is kinda useless in my opinion but for some reason manufacturers think you just have to put one of those little things on there to sell the product... They could have left it off and I would have still bought it... Or, hey Remington... Why don't you sell the Short cut with a beard groomer and ear / nose clipper all in one set... In a zip up travel bag perhaps... Make sure they all use the same charger... Just a thought... So... I like these things so much I made a Facebook page... I love the Remington SCC100R Short Cut Clipper ... &lt;...>... If they end up failing me I shall cry havoc and let slip the dogs of war on them !!! have a nice day... BMB
  221. This is a great product. I used to cut my hair with a corded clipper. Easy enough process, with good results, but it would take about 10 minutes and I would have to pass over the same area multiple times. With this product, I can do a clean and short cut in less than three minutes and I do not need to do multiple passes. This makes keeping my haircut short, and at the length I like it, very, very easy. To anyone that likes a short and close haircut, this product is a must.
  222. PLEASE SEE MY UPDATE #2 at end of review for battery rejuvenation procedure.<br /><br />Since I have a semi buzz cut style, it seemed increasingly silly to pay the barber $15 for the 5 minutes he spends on me. I purchased this clipper for less than the cost of two \\"professional\\" haircuts. It works well enough for me that I haven't gone back to the barber, but there are certainly some areas for improvement.<br /><br />1) The rechargeable batteries are non-replaceable, and they only last about a year or 10 recharges. Therefore, you'll have to buy an entirely new clipper every twelve months, or go through the warranty replacement hassle. Still, $26 replacement cost per year beats 10 professional haircuts at $15 each ($150).<br /><br />2) The little thumb dial that sets the haircut length does not have a firm notch for each setting. Because it's right under your finger in the natural grip position, it's easy to accidentally twitch it during the course of a haircut, usually to a shorter setting. And if you press the clipper against your head firmly, the cutter guides will \\"collapse\\" to a shorter setting. So that's two ways you can end up with a much shorter cut than you really wanted.<br /><br />3) While cutting your hair, you must remember to hold the clipper at the same angle to your head all over your head. Hold it at a perpendicular right angle to your noggin. If you tilt it back and forth as you run it around, the hair length becomes shorter as you tilt it more. I suspect this is why some folks have complained about getting a \\"patchy\\" haircut, with various lengths in different areas of the head - they were tilting the cutter back and forth on different parts of their head.<br /><br />4) With this clipper, you will still have difficulty creating a taper or sharp edge on the back of your neck. I just live with it, but some people may not like that. Or get your significant other to cut that last bit using the pop-up trimmer or the lowest setting on the hair length guide.<br /><br />By the way, I did, with great difficulty, disassemble the clipper in an attempt to replace the batteries. However, the batteries are spot-welded to their connectors. My past experience with trying to solder wires to batteries was unsuccessful, so I did not replace the batteries in this clipper. (Short rant: I'm seeing far too many small consumer items which have non-replaceable batteries spot-welded in place. I just threw away a $100 dollar ultrasonic toothbrush because the batteries were dead and welded in place. This is not environmentally nor consumer friendly - why should I toss 100's of dollars worth of electronic parts in the landfill just because the batteries, which could be replaced for less than $5, are welded permanently in place. And to add insult to injury, these appliances - like this clipper - will not run and perform their function when plugged into the charger. So once the battery is dead, you can't even choose to use it in the plugged in mode. Frankly, I think this kind of non-replaceable battery design should be illegal, for environmental protection reasons.)<br /><br />I'm giving it three stars because it's the only product like this available. If somebody came out with a similar curved edge clipper design with replaceable batteries, able to run while plugged in and has a more reliable hairlength control, I'd switch to that product - and I'd come back here and reduce this rating to 1 or 2 stars.<br /><br />>> UPDATE &lt;&lt;<br />Well, it's now 9 months after my review. I've used the Remington about once every two weeks during that period, for 5 minutes at a time. That's 18 times or 90 minutes of running time, always recharged between each use. The clipper has now become useless, incapable of running for more than 30 seconds when fully charged. So I saved the cost of 12 haircuts, 12 times $15 is $180. That's $180 I saved with this $26 purchase. While it's very annoying that the batteries in this device are sopoor and non-replaceable, the return on investment is pretty good and I'll probably buy another to replace this one.<br /><br />>> IMPORTANT UPDATE #2 &lt;&lt;<br />Now it's 12 months after purchase. I've discovered that you can substantially rejuvenate the batteries by occasionally COMPLETELY discharging them before recharging. This is contrary to the manufacturers instructions, which claim it's OK to leave the device plugged into the charger permanently. Instead, I now occasionally turn the cutter on and leave it running until it's completely discharged and stops running. I let it sit for 1/2 an hour, then I turn it on AGAIN and leave it running. I keep doing this, over and over again, until finally it will no longer come on even briefly. Then I give it a full overnight charge. The result is that it will now run for 8-12 minutes rather than 30 seconds, and that's more than enough time to give myself a haircut. So my advice - about every fourth haircut, you must give the batteries a completely thorough discharge in order to rejuvenate their recharge life. It might even make sense to rejuvenate the batteries soon after you first receive a new cutter, since apparently there are a lot of these cutters that have been sitting in warehouses for years, slowly draining the batteries.d I'll probably buy another to replace this one. >> IMPORTANT UPDATE #2 << Now it's 12 months after purchase. I've discovered that you can substantially rejuvenate the batteries by occasionally COMPLETELY discharging them before recharging. This is contrary to the manufacturers instructions, which claim it's OK to leave the device plugged into the charger permanently. Instead, I now occasionally turn the cutter on and leave it running until it's completely discharged and stops running. I let it sit for 1/2 an hour, then I turn it on AGAIN and leave it running. I keep doing this, over and over again, until finally it will no longer come on even briefly. Then I give it a full overnight charge. The result is that it will now run for 8-12 minutes rather than 30 seconds, and that's more than enough time to give myself a haircut. So my advice - about every fourth haircut, you must give the batteries a completely thorough discharge in order to rejuvenate their recharge life. It might even make sense to rejuvenate the batteries soon after you first receive a new cutter, since apparently there are a lot of these cutters that have been sitting in warehouses for years, slowly draining the batteries.

The only drawback that I have found is that due to its curved shape it is hard to cut your side burns and the areas around your ears. This is a minor inconvenience in my opinion for an otherwise great product.

  230. When I first got the Shortcut I really liked it. I had no problem getting an even trim and the adjustment mechanism was quick and consistent. However, the battery life began getting short. After a few months I had to plan ahead and charge the battery overnight before trimming my hair. That was fine for a few months, and then it got so bad that it couldn't last through a trim, and now it won't charge at all. I see no point wasting money repairing a bad design. I've gone back to my AC-powered Wahl trimmer. It may be bulkier, but it runs every time.
  231. I've read the reviews good and bad, and decided to purchase it anyway because the method of \\"combing\\" with this clipper seemed like it would be a much more natural action than trimming with normal hair-clippers. I am not disappointed. In fact, I've found that I can neatly trim the back of my neck with this. This is something I've never been able to do by myself with conventional clippers. The caveat is that it is a great tool for maintaining the length of a short haircut, but but not such a great tool for cutting hair that is not already in a crew cut. You will need a conventional clipper or a trip to the barber to start out. When I received it, I plugged it in to charge a whole day before use. Upon initial turn-on the motor started with an enthusiastic buzz, but then dropped in pitch and held a steady, but lower, speed. I initially thought that perhaps I had a unit with a bad battery that would not hold a charge, however I've used it extensively for a few weeks and it always keeps going for as long as I've needed to run it. I guess it just starts up \\"fast\\", but the lower steady speed is the normal speed. I'm happy that I can do a really quick trim to maintain my haircut once or more each week. It is cordless, so I can do this in the shower-stall (without water) to contain the mess and then just rinse away the trimmings, which are no bigger than shaving stubble. I also use it to maintain my beard. The comb-shape is not quite as natural a motion for that, but it is, nevertheless, effective, neat, and fast. In sum, I recommend this trimmer 100% for maintaining an existing crew-cut.
  232. I wanted a durable, easy-to-use, hair-trimmer to save money on haircuts. The product seems to be durably built BUT it certainly doesn't even come close to working as advertised. Even with the guides in place and all the settings in proper order - this clipper can barely take off a few strands of hair. The razor barely cuts and the guide is almost totally ineffective at positioning the hair for cutting. I think traditional clippers probably work better, as they use the scalp as the cutting platform. This clipper attempts to cut your hair from above by using hair attachments to position the hair against the blade. Well, like I said . . . . no recommendation here! The Remington Shortcut just . . . doesn't cut it!

My second pair was excellent since I never left them plugged up UNTIL I thought since they were working so good that everything was fixed and I left them on the charger. I think the faulty indicator allowed them to overcharge and killed the battery. I'm mad cause they were the nice shiny metallic ones (SCC-100RC) that I cant find anymore. Still for this price I'll prob grab a backup in 6+ months or so and unplug these when not using (I dont trust the indicator even though it works). NICE Product but SERIOUS Battery Issues!!   237. Great Product, Excellent seller.
  238. Excellent product if you like to keep your hair short. I use the setting that clips the hair down to about 1/8&#34; and use the clipper about once a week. You have to follow the instructions and use a circular motion while trimming or it won't work worth a darn. This is my second unit and the first lasted about 7 years.
  239. The battery on my first Remington Short Cut was deteriorating and finally wouldn't take a charge. The clipper was cutting unevenly, and I wasn't really happy with it, but I couldn't find a good alternative for the price. In reading some of the previous opinions, I learned that it is critical to be using the correct comb. It is virtually impossible to discern which comb is which from the instructions, but it does say the product arrives with one type of comb. Most people will probably need to change the comb. This was my error. I did change the comb, and the clipper is working perfectly giving me a nice even cut which I can do myself. The product is made for short and balding hair. In reading the instructions, I also discovered that I was cleaning it improperly, so I suspect that has helped its performance. I am now completely satisfied with the product, although I think the instructions could be clearer. I have also learned that I should RTFM on any product I buy.
  240. I saw an ad in a magazine for the Short Cut and thought it would be perfect for me. I've been buzzing my head for about a year now and I use no attachments so its as short as it gets without using a razor. I tried the Short Cut out this morning for the first time and I'll give it an A- overall. It did seem to come with some sort of charge but I charged it overnight to be safe, didn't want to run out of battery halfway. As others may have pointed out be aware that the attachment installed when you first open it is the 'balding' attachment which will have no change if you set the adjustable numbers higher, its for super short only. Normally I cut my hair about every 5 days. I sometimes do it more often but waiting a few days in between makes it easier to see what's been cut and what hasn't. I used the Short Cut this morning after about 3 and a half days or growth. Overall impression is it works very well. Being that I wasn't taking much length off it did take a few more passes than normal to get everything but it definitely does clip on both the back and forth movements. What I really liked is there seemed to be no way to cut myself which is a constant worry with regular clippers. It took a couple minutes to figure out the best angle to get all parts of my head; some parts cut better front to back, some side to side. It just depends on the way your hair grows. What threw me off at first is it doesn't make as much 'grinding' noise as its cutting. Its quieter overall which is nice, although the 'grinding' sound is usually my audible confirmation that I definitely cut a patch of hair. The front and sides cut pretty easily but where this thing really shines is in back. It only took me about 20 seconds to do the whole back of my head. With regular clippers I'd do the back and then have to spot check with a mirror. The only real problem I had was with my sideburns. Maybe its just the shape of my head but I couldn't get it to sit low enough to get them. I eventually found a way of doing it but it put the Short Cut dangerously close to my eyebrows so I'll have to be really careful. There is another small flat trimmer that pops out of the top but it seems to be a little shorter than the curved blade so it might make my sideburns a tad too short, I'll experiment next time. Just for comparison I whipped out my old clippers to see how close the Short Cut actually cuts. The clippers did cut a tiny bit shorter but it was totally negligible, the hair that fell into the sink was as thin as powder so the Short Cut seems to trim just as short. Pros: -cordless -curved blades hug my head well and cut both back and forth -30 minutes of runtime is adequate for a couple uses before recharging -nicking yourself is almost impossible -fits very well in my hand Cons: -some places are hard to reach with curved blade -needs to be shaken out once a minute or so, the hair tends to fall in instead of out as you cut so it can get clogged up but a quick shake or tap clears it out. -no carry case included -relatively long charge time (says 14-16 hours for full recharge) Overall I like it and I'll use it from now on. The small size and cordless power is especially nice for traveling too :)
  241. I am amazed at the versatility of the [[ASIN:B0015K9BXQ Remington Short Cut Clipper]]. I have keratosis on my scalp and favor a nearly bald hair length to facilitate medicating, which this delivers without undue interference with the keratosis scaling. But the adjustability also allows me to have more length on the sides and the back. A friend recently commented on how good my haircut was. When I told her that I did it and with what, she remarked that she wished it had been available when she went through chemotherapy years ago and lost her hair then grew it back. All this and it pays for itself in less then 3 uses!
  242. Doesn't work like I thought. Not satisfied.
  243. I've been shaving my head for a while now (not quite completely bald), with varying degrees of success determined by what kind of clippers I use. The Remington Short Cut Clipper however is by far the best brand of clippers I have used thus far, managing to get my hair as short and close as possible without leaving me bald. The curved design feature works very well and leaves things pretty even around the curve of the back of the head, and the cordless nature of the clipper doesn't hurt things either. If there's any downside to the Remington Short Cut Clipper, it's that the clipper's charge doesn't last as long as one may hope, but considering how well the clipper works for being what it is, this is only a minor gripe. All in all, you can certainly do worse in terms of self-grooming, and with that note alone, the Remington Short Cut Clipper is certainly worth a try at the very least.
  244. Works great, holds a charge, but their size measurements on the clips are not what they advertise. I normally cut my hair with a Wahl Clipper with the 3mm adapter, and have also used a Braun one with the 3mm. Both cut the same length. This one however, when using the 3mm, cuts longer and if I use the Braun after I still get a goot 1-2mm off.<br /><br />Other than that, not a bad product. Though I do think it's slightly more money than it's worth.
  245. I placed this order by mistake from my cellphone when I tried to cancel it in ten minutes them guys they denied me access .
  246. I could not get an even cut on #2. This is partially because the blade doesn't lift the hair like a standard trimmer. Also, the side of my head and the back of my neck (behind the ears) are apparently not rounded like the trimmer. I had to drop to the shortest cut to get my hair even over my entire head. It takes about 20 to 30mins to finish. I need to keep checking the cut using two mirrors. And, because the blade if vertical, the hair clippings are very fine and multiple passes are need. It is best to use this in the shower (w/o water running) or over the tub because the clippings are not easy to cleanup. It doesn't seem any better than a good cordless clippers/trimmers for buzz cuts and is worse for #2 and above.
  247. Being short on hair anymore I decided to chuck the constant ritual of visiting the barber and shave what was left. My son-in-law purchased a Remington Short Cut Clipper and offered to let me try his. I was very satisfied with the results and decided to purchase one for myself. It has now become a welcome part of my morning ritual. Easy to use, easy to clean, even a caveman could use it. I would highly recommend it. Donald
  248. It works fine up until maybe the 3rd time and then cutting quality goes down drastically.
  249. This is a great product for someone who wants to cut his own hair, without assistance. Read the instructions carefully before using. Unless you want a skin head, remove the comb that comes installed and install the adjustable comb. The only problem I have had is managing the fallen hair. Beware of hair falling down your back and sticking to your undershirt. Best to cut your hair shirtless, and take a shower afterwards.
  250. Its perfect if you like keeping your hair almost bald. Its well constructed the battery lasts long. You can give your self a nice short fade as well.
  251. I bought this clipper to cut my own hair because the shops around here charge me overall $5-8 more per haircut than they do my husband. I don't get a shampoo or any kind of cut or style that should cost more. I just get a regular short cut. This clipper paid for itself in the first 2-3 haircuts I gave myself. It charges fast & holds a charge very well. It's easy to clean. You can wash it out under running water to get the little hair chips out of it. It's light & shaped nicely to your hand. I have found that it doesn't cut as short as they say it does. I use the #2 setting for the top of my head & the 1.5 setting for the sides & back. I'm thinking of trying the #1 setting for the sides next time just to see if that's better. I also use the regular guard rather than the balding comb thing. I have found too that if you don't wait long between cuts it does better. I have very, very thick hair. It isn't overly fine but it isn't real coarse either. I get a better cut if I don't let it get too long. Overall it's a great tool & it makes it so that I don't ever have to spend 45 minutes in a chair trying to convince some timid hairdresser that I really DO know how short I want my hair & then still leaving disappointed that I never could get it like I wanted. Now, I do it myself & I'm a lot happier. And after the first 2 or 3 cuts, it had paid for itself so now it's just savings for me. I would buy a replacement of this clipper if mine broke today. I have been happy with it.
  252. I had been looking for clippers that would allow me to cut my own hair and give me the ability to trim my neck by myself. This is great and allows me to do what I need. It pays for itself in two uses based on what it used to cost for a haircut.
  253. If you're the type that likes to give yourself your own haircut from time to time, Remington's Short Cut Clipper is a solid tool if you have 'some' experience administering clipper cuts to your self.<br /><br />The blade shape of this clipper set was clearly designed for DIY Barbers as its curvature allows for a more intuitive feel on your head. Rather then mowing a set of clippers in difficult to reach areas such as the back of your head, this set is designed for users to blindly sweep back and forth like a hair brush and maintain even results.<br /><br />What I also found to particularly helpful is the fact that this device is cordless (albeit after a lengthy charge) which allows for quick and easy cleanup by taking this outdoors. Give this device a try if you're even a tiny bit curious and a fan of short cuts - the device will pay for itself within 2-3 uses.
  254. I was really excited when I first heard of this product. I used it at least half a dozen times, but after that I went back to my old straight-edge clipper. I found that this clipper simply isn't very efficient in time or effort. I typically just shave my head (the ol' buzz cut), and when using this clipper I had to go over my head a lot more times before I was satisfied that I had cut all my hair down to the level I wanted. Another minus: you have to plan ahead to make sure it is fully charged before you cut. I really wanted this product to work, but in the end I'm now back to my clipper.
  255. Have had mine for several years now and for the price, it's awesome.   278. I took a long time deciding which cordless clipper to buy, and I'm very glad I settled on this Remington Short Cut model. I opened the box, replaced the pre-packaged balding comb with the retractable one, set it to my desired length, and started cutting. It took me about 30 or 40 minutes to do my head since it had grown much longer than I would normally let it get. The clipper cut right through my hair with a number of passes. I had to stop occasionally and blow out the hair that had built up inside the comb, but it did a superb job. I switched back to the balding comb to do the back of my neck, and it gave me a professional-looking, clean job there, too.<br /><br />I can tell this model is not for everyone. In my opinion, it works best for short cuts and especially for the ones that are the same length all over. For my balding head, this clipper is ideal. I can see now that I'll simply have to give a few passes of the brush-like motion every other week or so, and I will easily maintain a look that rivals cuts from the barber.<br /><br />I used it right out of the box, and I'm very pleased. I highly recommend the brush-like Remington Short Cut clipper.<br /><br />Edit to add: I am still using this clipper as of this writing (Sept. 8, 2013), and it's still running strong. I cut my hair monthly, and I've had no complaints with this clipper.
  279. Love it. I shave my head. It only takes a couple of minutes.
  280. EDIT: **TWO years of weekly use and still works as new!!** Remember to oil before each use and thoroughly clean with a brush after. And always fully charge before using. Would love to see Remington to release a new model with USB charging of this item (They have it in other models).<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW:<br /><br />After the mixed reviews, I waited for a year and about 40 uses to write mine.<br /><br />I use this clipper every weekend, at 1, 1.5, 2 or 3, depending on the mood. Usually 1.5. In my case it works great, I have very thick hair and the blades chop it without problem. However, if I let my hair grow a bit more that the usual (2-3 weeks) and I want to use the shortest sizes, the clipper will have a hard time (And so do I), but in the end it can do the work.<br /><br />Regarding the maintenance I have found out that:<br /><br />1) You need to charge it ALWAYS. The motor requires the battery to be in its top capacity. I tried using the clipper until it really needed recharging but the motor couldn't keep working. ALWAYS CHARGE the clipper after using it. Because the battery is Lithium-Ion it can hold the charge adequately for at least a week in my case.<br />2) Also, ALWAYS clean and oil the clipper: Before using it I add a drop or two of oil for each centimeter along the blades. After using it I take a small brush, take out the guide and brush it through. I haven't even gone through half the oil bottle included, a recommended replacement would be 3-in-1.<br /><br />There are some cons, one is the charging adapter, it is 120V only, if I need to travel to somewhere else where the voltage is 100V or 220/240V, it will not work. This isn't a travel friendly item. (However Remington has a USB rechargeable clipper on their catalog!). Also it doesn't let to use the clipper while charging. The battery isn't replaceable.<br /><br />Everything taken into account, this is a great item, for me it only needs a 100-240V international adapter, a replaceable battery andit will be even better.<br /><br />I wrote to Remington about the adapter, they just said something along the lines of \\"Buy another one wherever you go\\". I don't know if they have it available everywhere.

  290. Conceptually the Remington Short Cut Clipper is ingenious and is a marvel. However, it pales in relative performance compared to the Wahl 5 Star Series Balding Clipper (Model 8100) that is also available for purchase on Amazon at these links: [[ASIN:B000VVT94G WAHL BALDING CLIPPER #8110]] [[ASIN:B0019QD8PI Wahl 5 Star Balding Clipper Kit]] [[ASIN:B0012KWUQE WAHL Balding Clipper (Model:8110)]] I have used both the Wahl and the Remington so I am able to make a direct comparison. Being cordless, the Remington Short Cut is underpowered compared to the Wahl 8100, which also happens to have powerful motor that is twice the speed of typical pivot motor clippers. This typically means that if the objective is to shave a head bald, the Wahl 8100 would be able to do it faster and better. However, the Wahl is slightly more expensive and one typically cannot cut your own hair with it; someone else will have to cut/clip your hair although it will typically take a mere 5 minutes or at most 10 minutes. Overall, I have found the Wahl 8100 to be much better than the Remington Short Cut.

  294. This trimmer is so cool! I don't use it on my head. I have been trimming my body hair, legs, chest, arms, etc., for years with regular hair clippers, the worst hour every few months of my life! With the Remington trimmer I can set the depth to one or two and simply rub it over my entire body. The result is an entire body trim at shaved close or slightly longer. I recommend this trimmer wholeheartedly. I can grab this thing at any second and trim the back of my neck or arms, where ever needed.   295. A great design crippled by a worthless battery. Although it's designed very well overall, it appears that the accountants specified the absolute cheapest battery possible. After one or two uses, it no longer holds a charge. You can't swap the battery for a better one, nor can you run the clipper directly from a wall outlet -- resulting in yet another toxic addition to the solid waste stream because that's where these units will quickly end up. For probably the cost of a few cents for a better battery, Remington has sullied their name and lost legions of customers forever. AVOID UPDATE March 16, 2015------------------------------------------- Apparently after reading my original review here, Remington customer service contacted me and sent me a replacement. I'll update this review, if needed, but only after I've had a chance to use the replacement unit a few times. Apparently, there's a manufacturer's code that's visible when you slide open the detail trimmer. Kudos to Remington for sending me a replacement, but I have no reason to believe that the battery on this one is any better (Remington said nothing about a re-engineered battery). So, my review will stand as-is for now. If you had your battery fail prematurely, I encourage you to send it back to Amazon for a refund, or if over 30 days ask Remington for a replacement. One can only wonder at how many of these were junked prematurely due to the bad batteries used, and at what $$$ cost to the customers and to the environment.

  304. Works great, easy to use. I thought the battery wasn't holding a charge. It would slow down in just a couple of minutes of use and die within about ten minutes. It turns out it just needed to be cleaned. Once you clear the clippings, it goes right back to full power, lasts for up to an hour. I've used it for over two years. It's rinseable so cleaning is quick and easy.

It did a great job while it lasted, but I would expect a product to last longer than this one did.
  313. My hair has been thinning for some time now and I feel I look better if I take it all off. Shaving it off can be a hassle, especially if you haven't done it for a while. At it's closest setting, this clipper allows me to easily and comfortably cut my hair so short that it almost looks like it's been shaved. This clipper is also great for trimming my beard and mustache, making it easy to clip all the hairs to the same length. CONS: This is the second time I have purchased these clippers. The first unit I purchased started having trouble taking/maintaining a usable charge after about 18 months of use. But these clippers are reasonably priced and do so much better than other clippers/trimmers I have tried that I decided I had to get a second set. I highly recommend these clippers.

  321. Cheap plastic and the battery wouldn't hold a charge and eventually died. I regularly buzz my hair down to the minimum, so I took off the comb, so it would also get jammed all the time. Still, it lasted 2 years or so.
  322. The main gripe on this clipper is its limited battery. Given the difficulty of disassembly, desolder and replacement, a legitimate caveat. I found, after solder-sucking the old dead nimh cell, that there are any number of battery upgrades on the market that are in the correct spec range for this unit, priced from 3-10 dollars.<br /><br />I did not re-solder my new Eneloop battery. Just stretch-taped the contacts to the wires and tacked the thing in place with a bit of sticky gel, then snapped the unit back together. My cost for battery surgery was about 3 bucks and 40 minutes' labor. It will take 15 minutes next time, now that I know what I'm doing.<br /><br />As for usage, I'm with the other reviewers. It works well once you settle on a style you can live with and learn to do it right. I've now been a DIY hair cutter for going on a year, and I don't expect I'll pay someone for another haircut unless this tool or one like it becomes unavailable.<br /><br />Batteries are no longer a limiting factor. Mechanically my year-old Shortcut works pretty much like it did new. When it dies I'll happily buy another just like it.
  323. If your hair never gets past 1/2 inch, then this product is for you. Otherwise, it simply doesn't work. If your hair is 1 inch or longer, forget about using this device. You can drag it across your head for half an hour and hardly see the difference, other than the unevenness it causes. What's more, even though I left it charging for three days, the thing only ran for 10-15 minutes before the charge ran out. I could go on, but basically, this product does not work and is a rip-off. Save your money and spend it on haircuts at the barber instead.
  324. The instructions need to be more detailed. Good thing I don't have much hair, it sounds like the battery is running down prematurely.
  325. I purchased the first one and stopped holding a charge after about 1 year. The second one lasted about 9 months and I contacted Remmington and they replaced it with another one that lasted about the same. I just purchased another one because there isn't another clipper that is as wide as this one. It works fine for up to a year, but then just doesn't hold a charge after that. I would charge it until the blue light goes off and in the middle of my hair cut, it would stop. I would have to keep on turning on and off the switch to get through cutting my hair. I do maintenance after every cut by rinsing, blowing the hair out and re oiling it and nothing ever works. I guess it's still worth it since a haircut cost a minimum of $15 and I cut my hair every 3 weeks. in one year I save about $250 plus my time and gas to go to the barber.
  326. I've had this for about a year, and it worked great until the battery died. It does not operate while plugged in, which makes it useless once the battery wears out and no longer retains a charge, which happened to me after about a year. It is not washable for a reason -- water will cause it to rust, especially around where the power cord plugs in. A clipper should at least be water resistant if not totally dunkable if you keep it in a moist environment such as a foggy shower room, or if you use water to wash the the cutter blade, which is the fastest way to clean it when it gets clogged, because some will unavoidably splash onto the rest of the device. Loved it while it worked, but now that I'm ordering a replacement, I am looking at alternatives.
  327. Does a good job, it hurts my skin a bit and I am used to cut my hair constantly. So far, it has not happen. The extra trimmer that pops out is a nice feature.

  337. I was paying $17 plus a $5 tip every 3 weeks on average ($22), I really liked the idea of saving close to $400 a year on haircuts. Not to mention the timing required to go to the barber at inconvenient times. The device does a very very good job of what it is made for, an all over/same length haircut. I have to admit I really like the look and the ease of care of my head! I get out of the shower, dry my head with a towel, and I'm done! I wear a hat, and no hat head! I ride my motorcycle with a helmet, no helmet head. I ride without a helmet (yeah yeah I know) but no hair standing straight up in the air. It is just such a nice feeling to not worry about your hair, like ever! As far as the battery. I would recommend to fully charge it before first use, then it is a good idea to fully run the device down to nothing, and then recharge it. And then after each subsequent haircut, just let the thing run out and then fully charge again. Many device batteries will die if not used for a month or so. So far mine is trucking along just fine by completing the process above. My thoughts on using the device: After a few passes on your head you'll want to just smack in on the palm of your hand to get the hair out of it, and maybe just pop the comb out and blow on the blades. Use the little brush to brush it for like 10 seconds or so when you are done. ***Update: It is now June 23, 2014. I have cut my own hair 18 times (at $22 a cut I've now saved $396 in haircuts). My battery is still running strong by letting it run out completely after every cut and then letting it charge fully every time immediately after use. ***Update: June 2, 2015. The unit is still running and the battery is just fine. I will note though, as others have said on here that the battery has always taken a long time to charge. But, as far as usage battery life, I have not noticed a decrease at all over a year now. ***Update: June 11, 2016. LOL, I must get the urge to write Amazon reviews every June apparently :P. I was writing some reviews on new things I bought and decided to update this one again. It has been over 2 years now and the thing still cuts and runs like a champ. I have had zero battery issues, and the unit still cuts my hair just as I need it to almost weekly now. I have learned a technique to use this just on the top of my head and then use regular clippers to &#34;fade&#34; the sides of my head for a more &#34;normal&#34; haircut. Like anything, practice makes perfect. Two years in and I actually look forward to listening to a podcast and cutting my hair. Perfect cut for me everytime. I get a haircut whenever I want. And I've saved a TON of money over the years which will only continue forward :). Whenever this thing does finally die I will be buying another one pronto as this is a must for me personally.probably take you awhile, subsequent cuts will go very quickly, it's actually kind of fun I hate to admit it. Anyway, that's it, hope this helps someone.<br /><br />***Update: It is now June 23, 2014. I have cut my own hair 18 times (at $22 a cut I've now saved $396 in haircuts). My battery is still running strong by letting it run out completely after every cut and then letting it charge fully every time immediately after use. Others have brought up a good point to remember to oil the unit every now and then as well. I've only oiled mine once so far, I should probably do more often. I now cut on level 1 and have a goatee. Everyone just knows me how I look currently. I still love the ease of this style and am considering trying the balding comb on level 1 just to see what it is like ;). In reading my old review, I do find that I use a beard trimmer behind the ears and at the nape of my neck as this unit does seem to leave longer hairs there (didn't notice it the first few cuts). But on the plus side, this thing trims my goatee faster than any other trimmer I own (including the beard trimmer LOL). I still rate this thing 5 stars and am still extremely happy with my purchase. It is just second nature to cut my own hair now. Like anything else, it took a few times to figure out exactly how you like to do it. Just be brave and keep trying :). I just wanted to take a moment to update my review.
  338. A great product for self haircuts. It's cheap, easy to handle and gives professional results. I selected a #2 blade and shaved my head. The process took 5 minutes and was comfortable. Four stars! Five stars if it collected discarded hair.
  339. As part of the Amazon Vine program, I recently received a review unit of the Remington Short Cut Clipper. Being somewhat \\"follicly challenged\\", I thought this might be a quick and easy way to keep my hair trimmed to its shorter length without having to beg and plead for the wife to give me a hair cut. Generally speaking, it works pretty well. I probably should have started out with a setting of 2 rather than 1.5, as 1.5 is quite a bit shorter than I normally go...<br /><br />The idea here is that you can cut your hair with the same motions you'd use to brush it. The cutting head is curved, so you have more surface contact as you move across your hair. There's less of a chance for gouges and bald spots. There's also a pop-out trimmer on the top that you can use to get hairlines cut properly. After the initial charge, I started brushing away to see what would happen. In the course of about five minutes, I was the proud owner of a haircut that wouldn't be out of place on a Marine base after six weeks of basic training. My wife came in and went over a few places where I hadn't gotten the same level of cut and/or couldn't see. We both agreed that her hair cuts are better using a trimmer with a #2 attachment.<br /><br />On the plus side, it is tailored for the short-all-over hair styles, and it works well in that niche. It's best to make sure you're standing over a sink or on a towel to catch some of the hair that falls. The style of the attachment does catch a fair amount of the hair, and you can simply pop it off to empty it out every couple of minutes. On the down side, it can leave some uneven patches on the shorter settings if you don't happen to have a perfectly spherical noggin. I have a couple of small bumps on my head that have less hair than the surrounding territory now...<br /><br />This won't replace my wife's efforts, as her results are better. But with a higher length setting, this could be ideal for those 3rd week touch-ups to keep from waking up with strange parts in my hair. And if you're the type that goes for the nearly bald/razor stubble look, then this would be ideal for getting and keeping your hair (or lack thereof) at that perfect length.ts in my hair. And if you're the type that goes for the nearly bald/razor stubble look, then this would be ideal for getting and keeping your hair (or lack thereof) at that perfect length.
  340. I was pleasantly surprised by how well my first haircut turned out. Never having cut my own hair before, I wasn't sure what would happen. I purposefully cut my hair on a Saturday morning so I could still make it to my barber if I ended up butchering my hair. Instead I got a haircut that doesn't look that much different than what I would have paid $28 for. As the manual recommends, I started out with a longer setting and then worked my way down. I ended up using the 1 1/2 setting for the sides and back of my head and 3 for the top. This yields an extremely short haircut on the sides and back with just a little bit of hair on top of the head. I've had a couple of friends look at my haircut so far and neither of them could tell it was done by myself at home until I told them so. My only real complaint is what others have mentioned: The sideburn trimmer doesn't work that well. I ended up using a small pair of scissors to clean up the hairline around my ears. Because it's really difficult to hold the clipper at the correct angle to make a clean line at the back of one's own head, I ended up using my Body Groomer for that. All in all, this is a good product that will pay for itself in just a haircut or two.

  342. This is a very sweet little unit. My mother is a professional hairstylist and has cut my hair all my life (44yr). Unfortunately, I don't get to see her as often as I'd like anymore and since I usually keep a short haircut I started to look for a product that could maintain my haircut. A little searching on the 'net yielded this beauty. This unit does exactly what it advertises. I use a middle setting every week or so and my hair it cut to perfection for me. I also have a mustache and small beard and am able to keep it just as closely trimmed and neat with the Remington ShortCut. Yes, it does take an overnight charge to get it working initially, but I can cut my hair several times on one charge and have never had it quit while I was in the middle of a cut. My wife and mother have both commented on how good of a job the unit does to keep and maintain my haircut. It also is wonderful for trimming your neck below the hairline. Just set it to the lowest setting and that neckhair is gone. The little trimmer that is on the top of the unit is neat for trimming the hair around your ears and also trimming up the corners of my beard. All in all, a great product!
  343. I've been cutting my husband's hair at home for over 14 years now. He has fine, soft, silky hair on the sides and the back but unfortunately has a very deep receding hairline and not much hair on top (male pattern baldness).<br /><br />His hair was getting shaggy around his ears and the back of his neck so I decided to test the Remington Short Cut Clipper by giving him a touch-up haircut. As per the instructions, I removed the balding comb that was attached and replaced it with the normal clipper comb. Then I dialed the length to setting 4 and started in. The Clipper's curved blade worked easily and smoothly but I couldn't see much difference in the hair length. I dialed the setting to 2 and went over the back and sides of his head again. It was quite easy and light to use and I really liked that it operated smoothly and fairly quietly. His hair was evened out and looked really nice. The only problem was that he still had a lot of little neck hairs and the hairline at the back of his neck needed to be evened up.<br /><br />I pushed the button to bring out the little detail blade and tried it on the back of his neck. That did not work well at all. I really couldn't see that it was doing much good. As a matter of fact, it seemed to be pulling rather than shaving. We tried it a bit longer but it just wasn't working well there and Dave was losing patience with all the pulling...even though, I swear, I was trying to be very gentle.<br /><br />I pushed the button again to retract the little detail blade and pulled off the comb attachment from the shaver. That worked superbly! Dave said it felt fine and there was no pulling or gouging. It shaved the little neck hairs very closely and the back of his neck looked and felt great. It only took about 30 seconds to even up the neck line and clean up the neck hairs. Success!<br /><br />As I said earlier, there is not a lot on top to work with and since this was just a touchup haircut, anyway, I didn't need to cut anything there today. He prefers to keep his comb-over hair on top and since the balding comb actually gives a very close buzz cut I doubt that we will ever be using that particular attachment.<br /><br />This haircutter was lightweight and felt good in my hand. The curved blade made it very easy to cut hair evenly. I also like the fact that it is much less noisy than the electric [[ASIN:B000FRWNLW Vidal Sasson VSCL802 10-Piece Haircutting Kit]] that we have been using for several years now. It was very nice not having a cord to drag around, too. The Remington Short Cut Clipper comes with a handy little brush so the clipper clean-up was easy. I just brushed the cut hair away from the blade. It also comes with a small bottle of oil so re-lubing the blade is easy.<br /><br />The whole shaver can be rinsed under water. The directions recommend re-lubing the blade after doing that. I felt that for this first haircut just brushing off the blade worked just fine.<br /><br />My biggest pet peeve about Remington Short Cut Clipper is that once you unpack it from the box there is no easy way to keep all the pieces organized and together. I think a plastic storage case where all the pieces had a place would have been wonderful. At the least, I think some sort of a soft cloth storage bag with a draw string opening should have been included. I currently have mine stored in a freezer zip lock bag. It is fine for now but I am careful with it since there is no added protection for the shaver or accessories. The other thing that disappointed me was that it takes 14-16 hours to get a full charge into the unit. It will not operate while it is charging, either. The charge light is quite a bright blue. While it was charging on the bathroom counter it really did double as a quite bright nightlight.<br /><br />Overall, I give this product 3 stars. In summary,it's easy to use and cuts hair evenly and smoothly but I do not like the detail blade - it pulled rather than shavedand I think it could easily cut tender ears or the skin on the back of the neck. The curvature of the main blade worked very well and made it very easy to trim hair. It's relatively quiet to operate but there is nothing provided in the box to keep all the pieces and parts organized and together. And finally, it takes a long time to charge up.in on the back of the neck. The curvature of the main blade worked very well and made it very easy to trim hair. It's relatively quiet to operate but there is nothing provided in the box to keep all the pieces and parts organized and together. And finally, it takes a long time to charge up.

  349. Basically, this is a portable, hand-held Flowbee that has only 4 settings: short, very short, very very short, and bald. The longest setting is supposed to be about an inch, but a half-inch would be more like it. And that's with the standard brush attachment. There's also a \\"shaved head\\" attachment if you want a truly bald head.<br /><br />I carefully read the other reviews before ordering this unit. I had mixed feelings about what I expected, but I've been happily surprised at what I received. It seems to work fine, although the \\"vacuum\\" created by the machine is very weak. While running the unit over your head, you'll feel a constant shower of little tiny hair particles raining down on your head, neck, and shoulders. There is just enough suction to make a pad of hair coat the inside of the \\"brush\\" so that you have to clean it out often. But that's my only complaint, and frankly, it's not much of one.<br /><br />If this one breaks or wears out, I'll probably order another one. And from me, that's the biggest compliment anything is likely to receive.<br /><br />Additional note: I've used this unit for awhile now, and I still have no other complaints. However, I've discovered that you have to use it every few days (once or twice a week, depending on your rate of hair growth), or it gives a choppy response. That's because the unit is designed to \\"keep\\" your hair short, not \\"cut\\" it short. If your hair grows more than a quarter-inch or so, it just won't function the way you'd wish.

  358. Well, I checked out other reviews for this product and, sure enough, many others have the same problem: the battery doesn't keep a charge after a short time. I'd have to consider myself lucky, though. I've had mine for 2 years and only recently has it been failing to charge up. It's too bad because, unlike some other reviews I've read, I've been able to give myself pretty good haircuts with this thing; in that respect it works great (Oh,incidentally for those having trouble with the back and sides of their heads--try using a hand-held mirror in front of you while standing in front of a regular mirror; I found that works well). I would hope that Remington has improved the quality since I first bought it because I'd sure like to get a newer, better one. They need to appreciate that if they want repeat business they need to make a quality product!

  382. I bought one of these trimmers about a year ago and so far here are my observations<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Consistent length trimming when trimming your won hair.<br />- Length wheel that locks at the desired length so you don't accidentally cut it too short because it inadvertently clicked to a shorter position. (Be sure it's locked firmly into the desired length before trimming.)<br />- Two length attachments with further variable length achievable with the locking adjustment wheel.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- It is safe to say that EVERY single time I use this thing I accidentally turn it off or on because they (stupidly) put the on/off button on a handling surface. (My dang Galaxy S3 does this also b/c the power button sits where you hold the device. I hate that.)<br />- Battery consistency is flaky. Not sure if it's the individual one I bought or all of the batteries in these trimmers are flaky. I turn it on, after 20-30 seconds it slows down to a low trim speed.<br />- I'd actually like a slightly longer trim gate for the top of my head, which I like a little longer. Can't win them all.<br />- The trim teeth are at an angle I would guess trims that well. It's at a 90 degree angle to your scalp when I would have faced the teeth toward the incoming hair. A 90 degree angle probably makes it possible to move the trimmer in two directions to cut.<br /><br />Overall Recommendation:<br />I'd say it's a good purchase and I recommend it.<br />As a military guy, short hair is the rule but I don't want to have to go get a haircut every week or two.<br />It's easier just to do it yourself. (A practice I got good at in Afghanistan where there weren't any barbers.)<br /><br />Recommendations to the Manufacturer<br />- Move the power button to where it belongs, down on the end where you plug it in and out of the place where fingers are supposed to press<br />- Beef up the battery so it lasts at least 10 minutes of cut time.<br /><br />Follow-on Comment<br />- I tried some razor oil which seemed to help with the battery problem. Probably should have tried that earlier but it helpsoil which seemed to help with the battery problem. Probably should have tried that earlier but it helps
  383. I've owned this product for almost 6 months now and I've been very happy with it. No fuss and very easy to use.<br /><br />Regarding the battery: I suspect that this device uses Nickel Cadmium batteries. Because of this, I make sure to fully discharge it before my next charge (that is, the low battery indicator lights up AND the clipper turns off a couple seconds after I try to turn it on). If I don't do this, my clipper's battery will experience the \\"memory effect\\" which is inherent in nickel cadmium (or similar) based batteries. I make sure to avoid overcharging it as well as it might experience the \\"lazy effect\\" which is, again, inherent in nickel cadmium batteries.
  384. As another reviewer stated, these do not accommodate for places where your head is not round such as the sides. I ended up getting it too short on the top and the top edge of the side by going over and over a spot that it wouldn't touch. By doing this, the spot it was touching just got way too short while the spots on either side of it did not. My head shape does not conform exactly to the curve of the blades and that means it will not cut evenly. It does sound like a good idea in a product but that's all it is; marketing. I could try to return it to the manufacturer but it's just not worth my time. Bottom line is I took a gamble with this one and lost. I went with a traditional clipper from Wahl that have a cord and not batteries so I don't have to worry about charging. They work much better than this and cost about the same.

As it is, getting burnt once is enough for me. TIP: To get the most run-time from your unit, be sure to clean often as per manual instructions. Believe it or not, any little bit of hair caught down in the head increases the current drain dramatically.

  399. The design of the clipper is flawed in that the blades of the clipper moves back in forth in the vertical direction (think same direction as your hair stands). So what this means is in order for your hair to actually get cut, the hair has to be pushed into the blades unlike conventional clippers where the clipper is perpendicular to the hair so as the hair just slides into the clipper.<br /><br />But there's really no good reason for this...they really could have designed it with double horizontal blades (like a T ).<br /><br />So the end result is an uneven cut unless you go over your head a million times. This also means that you will end up with a million tiny pieces of hair because of the way it cuts. I also had to constantly take off the guard and knock off the hair before it would start cutting again.<br /><br />I put up with this only because I didn't want to spend more money on another set. However, since the clippers broke after only a few months, I'm now in need of another pair of clippers.<br /><br />These aren't worth the time. I would stay away from these unless they change the cutting blade design. Then I would try them again.

  430. I've been cutting my own hair for 15 years... ever since a particularly bad haircut from a barber in 1993. I don't use anything except a standard Conair-type clipper and the trimmer function on the back of my electric razor. The whole process is a little time consuming and there are many times when I make blind cuts, which is basically using my fingers to determine length while not being able to see any of the action. When I saw this Remington Short Cut Clipper online I thought I might have stumbled into a perfect solution for my hair cutting needs. The design is very innovative, allowing for cutting with either hand that goes more quickly because the blades are wider and they're shaped to follow the contour of the head. After receiving the product and trying it on my own hair, I have to give it just an average rating. Here is what the Remington does right: 1. The fact that it's cordless is a huge plus. No cords get in the way, which has always been an issue with traditional clippers. 2. The bi-directional cutting is wonderful, and combined with the ambidextrous design this makes the clipper equally useful in either hand and in both directions. 3. The pop-up trimmer is the perfect size to trim around the ears. It is longer and narrower than typical back-of-the-electric razor trimmers, which makes the hard-to-reach places and angles much easier to navigate. Here are the issues I have with the Remington: 1. Unless you want a true short-all-over cut, this clipper isn't for you. My hair is longer on the top, but very short on the sides and in the back. I like to start short on the bottom and then blend it with longer hair as I move up. That strategy doesn't work well with this trimmer. My personal attempt resulted in choppy cuts that had to be smoothed over with regular clippers. 2. The contour shape of the plastic length attachment and the blades are only good for the round parts of your head. The sides of my head don't happen to bulgeout in a rounded fashion, so it made trimming the sides of my hair very difficult. Navigating around the ears was also trouble. 3. The plastic attachment quickly fills up with cut hair and needs to be emptied. I would prefer that it just fell off and didn't accumulate in the clipper. Maybe I am not the intended user for this product. If I just wore buzz cuts or crew cuts, this product would get 5 stars from me. With that type of haircut, you really will get a quick and clean cut. But I think others like me would appreciate a little more flexibility in dealing with blending slightly longer hair.
  431. The devil is in the details, or so the saying goes. With the RSCC, Satan's been forced out of the hair-cutting business.<br /><br />Over the years, I've become a proponent of self-cut short hair. It's easier to manage and I don't have to deal with barbers who no longer want to be called barbers but aesthetes.<br /><br />The normal clippers I use while perfectly adequate always seem to leave a section of hair longer or shorter than others. This is very frustrating. The Short Cut Clipper cuts hair perfectly to the same desired length with every pass. The design of it means I can hold it like a comb and move it through the hair as with a comb.<br /><br />The curved cutting clippers that can be raised and lowered with a clicker setting combined with a guard ensures the DIY barber will not be able to give himself (or herself?) a bad haircut. Highly recommended and a joy to own.<br /><br />**Update (6/22/2009): Using the Remington Short Cut continues to be a pleasure however, I have finally found one shortcoming: the build-up of hair in the teeth and comb of the implement really impedes continued hair-cutting past a few (2 or 3) minutes. This would have brought down the star rating from 5 to 4 or 4.5.
  432. I bought this trimmer at a Linens N Things going out of business sale for less than $20. I used it to give my husband a much needed haircut (I usually cut his hair but have been too busy..)with terrific results! Once I was comfortable with the unit I gave him a great (short) haircut in minutes. The best part is he can now cut his hair weekly himself without any fuss and he no longer has to wait for me. I think I love this new gadget more than he does! ;-)<br /><br />Pointers:<br />* charge fully before using.<br />* read the furnished manual ;-)<br />* use only when a very short cut is desired.<br />* can be used in the shower (before taking a shower!) by themselves for a weekly - no mess no fuss self-haircut n cleanup!<br />* Great gift from spouses to their husbands! ;-)<br />* also great for the busy road warrior who doesn't have time to find a salon while on the road. It's small compact size and tiny charger fits readily into luggage!<br /><br />All in all very worth the price!<br /><br />Update 2012: I deducted a star since one day the comb broke the Remington was accidentally dropped into the sink making the device mostly useless. Since the Remington was only dropped a few inches I expected the comb to be sturdier. While it was still functional the Remington saved us quite a bit of money on hair cuts and allowed my husband to maintain a good appearance while I was out of town for an extended duration.<br /><br />The quality of the Remington was such I would buy another, but since then we found the [[ASIN:B004QHDJNI Philips Norelco Qc5340/40 Hair Clipper Pro]] which my husband absolutely loves!! The Philips QC5340 allows much better precision on length as well as longer lengths up to a #13 comb! With only two attachments to worry about the Philips is a Winner!
  433. I'm very pleased with the clipper. For me it's serving two for the price of one as I've short beard which gets evenly trimmed at setting 4\\". Perfect for me. Highly recommend it. The only reason I don't give 5 stars is because i prefer to have a little longer hair on head [5 or 6\\"] would have got my all 5 stars!!! Still the best so far!!!

It also works great on body hair. Some reviewers complained about it being curved and this causing a problem for cutting non head-shaped places but I have not experienced any problems with is.   446. Shortcut Clipper by Remington<br /><br />I bought this primarily to cut my sideburns. I often found myself going to the barbershop mainly to get my sideburns trimmed back. I keep my hair fairly short, a number 3 on the sides, number 4 on top. I would imagine it would work well on facial hair, also.<br /><br />I followed the directions and charged it overnight. Was very careful to set the length on the controls and took care of my sideburns in about 5 seconds. I may try doing my whole head. For now, I'm happy with it. This thing pays for itself after skipping only two haircuts in my neighborhood.<br /><br />Highly recommended for people with short hair, either facial or on their head that don't want to be bother with going to the barbershop.<br /><br />Gunner August 2008
  447. My husband has male pattern baldness--just some fuzz now on top and a nice fringe of fine hair from ear to ear. He's been clippering his own hair for quite a while now. Says that someone who can comb his hair with a washcloth doesn't need to spend money on haircuts. He does buzz it all over from time to time, but lately has just been neatening the edges, and chopping all the dome fuzzies.<br /><br />Things to know: This thing takes a long time to charge. Like a day. The curved shape is nice to hold--fits in your hand comfortably, but it doesn't necessarily match the shape on one's head. The balding comb is pretty fragile. I thought it was a goner trying to get it off. The important thing to know and what you gain by reading instructions is that the balding comb is installed and if you use it from the get-go, you get a buzz. Even on the other lengths, this is intended to give a nice short haircut. So if you're just looking to trim longer hair, you should probably look elsewhere.<br /><br />I think once he gets the hang of it, this will be a nice trimmer for him. It did a nice job on the edges.
  448. This is a very good clipper for tight haircuts and a great price for what you get. The first time I used it, I ended up with great results. The balding comb will do just that on the lowest setting. Only drawback was the maximum length you can get is 1/2 inch, so you have to like it short. All in all, much easier than any other clipper out there (especially if you cut your own hair).
