  452. >> Nov. 29 Update: &lt;&lt;<br /><br />I wrote the review below after using the clipper once. Sadly, the second time around was not as good.<br /><br />The clipper stopped clipping after a few minutes of use. I cleaned it thoroughly and I restarted and it worked for a few more minutes. Another cleaning followed and... so on. It was a time consuming process.<br /><br />Then, as I was taking a shower, I heard a strange buzzing sound. It turns out it was the clipper that decided to turn itself on, inside a drawer. The on/off switch could not stop it but some vigorous shaking did. A few minutes later, as I was discussing the incident with my wife, I heard the buzzing again. More shaking pacified the clipper again, I don't know for how long.<br /><br />It appears that, the more one uses this device, the harder it is to use. I would not have bought it, had I known that what I just shared with you was going to happen.<br /><br />>> End of Nov. 29 update &lt;&lt;<br />_____________________________________________<br /><br />I must start with a confession: I used to be a Flowbee man well... until last night. I hate hair-cutting/sculpting/design establishments for several reasons but I won't go into that now. The short of it is that I've been cutting my own hair for the past 15 years or so.<br /><br />I ordered this clipper because Amazon had it on sale and I thought I'd give it a try. Somewhat to my surprise, I like it and I will use it to cut my hair. I will also use it to cut my boys' hair because they hate the 'professional' jobs too.<br /><br />This is sold as a 'short cut' device but, as someone famous used to say, it all depends on what the meaning of 'short' is. The manual suggests that the 'longest' setting is at 1/2 inch but, in practice, you can easily do 1-inch and even longer haircuts.<br /><br />The operation is easy: after you charge the device, you turn it on and you begin 'combing' your hair with it. My wife started it but, after a few minutes, I became confident enough to do it myself with her watching and cheerleading me. I works fast but you may have to take it apart and clean it if your hair is too long to begin with. I had to do that. The end-result is something that could easily pass for a $20 salon job.<br /><br />Technical details:<br /><br />- The blade's shape approximates the curvature of the skull, making for a more even cut.<br />- Rechargeable - needs no batteries for its lifetime.<br />- The blade guard can be removed for cleaning.<br />- Can be cleaned with water or a brush.<br />- Comes with 2 combs, one of them allowing for a 'near-bold' length while protecting the skin.<br /><br />My big issue with this device is that you get:<br /><br />- the clipper itself<br />- the regular comb<br />- the bold-cut comb<br />- the brush<br />- the 1/8 ounce oil bottle<br />- the charge adapter<br /><br />It adds up to SIX discrete, small or very small (the brush, the oil bottle) and easy to misplace items and there is no storage box or bag included. I would have gladly paid a few more dollars if such a necessary convenience was added. Since this is not the case, I am taking away 1 star from what should have been an easy 5-star evaluation.to do it myself with her watching and cheerleading me. I works fast but you may have to take it apart and clean it if your hair is too long to begin with. I had to do that. The end-result is something that could easily pass for a $20 salon job.<br /><br />Technical details:<br /><br />- The blade's shape approximates the curvature of the skull, making for a more even cut.<br />- Rechargeable - needs no batteries for its lifetime.<br />- The blade guard can be removed for cleaning.<br />- Can be cleaned with water or a brush.<br />- Comes with 2 combs, one of them allowing for a 'near-bold' length while protecting the skin.<br /><br />My big issue with this device is that you get:<br /><br />- the clipper itself<br />- the regular comb<br />- the bold-cut comb<br />- the brush<br />- the 1/8 ounce oil bottle<br />- the charge adapter<br /><br />It adds up to SIX discrete, small or very small (the brush, the oil bottle) and easy to misplace items and there is no storage box or bag included. I would have gladly paid a few more dollars if such a necessary convenience was added. Since this is not the case, I am taking away 1 star from what should have been an easy 5-star evaluation.

  460. There is a recurring theme in these reviews. Users complain that this clipper loses its battery capacity. They conclude this because the clipper bogs down during a clip session - the motor slows down and eventually stops. I was having the same problem and figured the clipper was a lemon. But I went back and started re-reading the reviews here to see what others had experienced. I found one review where the reviewer claimed he had brought his clipper back to life by lubricating it with clipper oil. I had some clipper oil in the house and figured it was worth a shot. And presto! A few drops of clipper oil on the blades and the clipper came back to life. In fact it was actually working better than when it was new. It maintained full speed throughout the cut, which it had not done since a month after I bought it. I now put a couple of drops of clipper oil on the blades before each use. The clipper works beautifully. I clip down to stubble once a week. The clipper does a very fast and complete job. The curved shape really speeds the process up compared with flat clippers. I am now a very satisfied customer. I use [[ASIN:B000B9SFQG Wahl 4-Ounce Blade Oil]] but I'm sure any clipper oil would work.
  461. This is a 1-star product for one reason, and one reason alone: the battery recharge is defective. After just a few uses, the unit stops charging and can only hold a charge for 5 to 10 seconds (if that). At the time of writing this review, this product doesn't hold a charge at all and won't even turn on anymore. I've only had it for a year or so and only used it about 5 or 6 times. During the first few uses, the unit worked great, and I would have highly recommended it! The battery takes forever to recharge (a full day!), but as long as I remembered to plug it in a day or two before I wanted to do the actual hair cut, it worked flawlessly. It's easy to use and easy to clean. If the recharge actually worked, I'd probably give this product a 3.5 or 4-star review (losing a point or so for the long recharge and inability to use while plugged in). From what I've read in other places, this particular model has been discontinued. If Remington ever releases an updated version that actually works, I may give it a try. In the meantime, I recommend that you find an alternative clipper set, perhaps the [[ASIN:B002C741MW Philips Norelco QC5170 180-Degree Hair Clipper]].

  474. I have used the Remington Short Cut Clipper for five years. My first lasted forty months, until the battery would no longer charge. Spreading the purchase price of (then) $24.95 over 40 months, it cost just 0.63 cents per haircut . I keep mine plugged in all the time, when not in use, and this may or may not prolong battery life (I haven't identified the type of battery, in order to determine best practice for charging). Regardless, this clipper is a great way to cut your hair without the risk of making an accidental divot. It takes me about fifteen to twenty minutes to cut my hair--far less time than it would take to drive to a barber shop, wait my turn, and receive a haircut. If you value self-sufficiency, this a great tool! I keep one active and one in reserve. I haven't had the negative experiences reported by some owners, but do want to echo reports that the clipper comes with the &#34;balding attachment&#34; installed, rather than the adjustable comb. Make sure to swap the adjustable comb for the &#34;balding&#34; attachment unless you want a &#34;buzz cut&#34;. I recommend this product without reservation.

  481. TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE and TERRIBLE! There are two good things in an otherwise vast sea of failure for this device. One: It is cordless. Two: It fits easily in the garbage can. I bought this clipper to replace an old Wahl clipper that had outlived its usefulness. I thought that the description was pretty innovative, and waited for it to come out. However, this thing is absolutely abysmal at the actual job of cutting hair. I keep my hair cut very short, usually a one or a two with other clippers. It should be noted that on this clipper, the #1 setting will scalp you bald. So I went to the task of starting with a #2 trim, which didn't seem to be cutting any hair at all. I went down to a #1.5 which cut my hair very short, but it was acceptable. That is, until in the middle of cutting my hair, the guide slipped down to setting #1, scalping me on the side of my head. Beyond that, the teeth in the comb constantly fill up with hair, having to be emptied out with a great deal of frequency. It will still cut hair while it's full, but it will keep mulching the hair that is trapped in there, creating a fine dust that spreads everywhere as the hair trapped in the guide comb keeps getting re-cut. In short, stay FAR, FAR AWAY from this, you'll be doing yourself a HUGE favor!
  482. The Remington \\"Short Cut\\" hair clipper is, just as the name implies, for short haircuts. I had been considering going to a shorter style for a while, and thought this would be a good opportunity to move in that direction. So I gave it a shot and was pleased with the result.<br /><br />The longest finished length this clipper will allow is somewhere between ¼ and ½ inch. The adjustable length comb has ½ inch teeth, but the curved blade comes up into the teeth some way, making the finished length of the hair less than the length of the teeth. The depth of cut is controlled by a thumb wheel.<br /><br />Do not try to use this clipper if your hair has any length at all. If your hair is long enough to fall over on its own the clipper will just bend it over and won't effectively cut it. It is obviously intended to give an even trim to very short hair styles, with the hair standing up as it passes the blade.<br /><br />As others have noted, this clipper will not take you to a short hairstyle, but it will very effectively maintain one. If you have longer hair, your best bet is to go to a stylist for the initial cut and use the trimmer to maintain the look. While it won't replace professional haircuts, it will reduce the need for them from 8 to 12 times a year to one or two.<br /><br />The extendable trimmer works well for cleaning up edges and mowing around ears and other obstructions. You are still going to want somebody to help even-up things in the back for you.<br /><br />The unit is relatively quiet, does not heat up like many clippers do, and fully charges in about 14-hours. One charge is plenty to complete a good trimming. The teeth and blade are removable for cleaning and the instructions say the unit can be immersed in water for cleaning (although I didn't try it).<br /><br />You will want to do the trimming with a towel or other \\"drop cloth\\" around your shoulders and quite a few fine trimmings will end-up on the floor. When all is said and done the Remington Short Cut Clipper does the job, and will pay for its self with just a few missed haircuts.y for its self with just a few missed haircuts.
  483. After three weeks clippers seem to work great. The clippers were advertised as in stock and could be delivered the next day. However, since I took advantage of the free shipping they did not get put in the mail until five days after they were purchased.
  484. So, If I want a buzz cut for 8 years (how long I have been using the Shortcut) , I will have a buzz cut every week or two. Lets say every two weeks.<br /><br />$15 x 56/2 = $420 per year for a barber to maintain my haircut. Thats not even including tips<br />$420 x 8 years = $3360<br />This is my 3rd Shortcut over 8 years.<br />$30 x 3years = $90<br />So I pay approx. $90<br />Thats a savings of around $2850 over 7 years, Plus about 180 hours (7.5 days!!!!) of commuting and waiting time.<br /><br />My first Shortcut was damaged because I accidentally left it outside and it rained. The second Shortcut was damaged because I was rinsing it out with water and the battery went out - although the product claims that you can rinse it off, I wouldnt recommend it. Just brushing it off with a brush or can of air-duster should be enough.<br /><br />I think they modified the battery at some point - I feel that the latest one I purchased holds a lot more charge and although it is the same aesthetic design, is somehow holding up longer than the last one.<br /><br />My third Shortcut is working perfectly after about 4-5 years - no problems. I think Remington did something to improve the battery life. I am noticing that it holds the charge alot better than my first two. Maybe Im lucky. If it ever goes out I will just buy another one - after 2 cuts the device pays for itself.<br /><br />So if you are happy with a buzz cut and dont want to get too creative with your hair style - this thing is the bomb!!!
  485. I bought this trimmer after using a conventional hair cutter to do my own hair for the past year. I have to say that the Remington Short Cut Clipper is fantastic for doing your own hair IF you want it very short. I tried several lengths starting with 3 and found that it was rather uneven until I got down to 1.5 or 2. I liked the 1.5 best so have been using that setting. It is quite easy to get an even cut with the curved comb and the ability to cut while moving the trimmer forward and backwards is great. For the price it is a great buy. I also have used it to trim my chest and stomach hair. The curved comb can sometimes make this difficult but overall it works well. The pop-up straight trimmer is a little too narrow for easy use so I just use my conventional trimmer for sideburns instead of the pop-up.
  486. This is a pretty amazing invention. My wife has always had to shave my head, but now I can do it myself. This shaver is comfortable to use and makes quick work of my thick head of hair. It holds a charge really well, and clean up is a snap. Highly recommend...
  487. [[ASIN:B0015K9BXQ Remington Short Cut Clipper]] I like this product for me and my son. I am cutting mine on the 3 setting which is short but not shaved bald and doing it weekly. I like the way it cuts and looks. I am cutting my son's setting 4 on top and setting 3 on sides and back of head. His hair was thick, and it took much longer to do his, but even his mother liked it. With this device it is much harder to make a mistake than the old clippers. I would say it is great for an older balding guy.
  488. I bought this model for my husband 9 years ago in an attempt to get him to cut his own hair...took a little practice, but he is successfully able to cut it (and it even looks decent!) He does keep his hair super short. I bought another one only because after the 9 years of using it every 2-3 weeks the battery doesn't stay charged. The only thing I don't like about it is the fact that you can't use it while it's plugged in and charging.
  489. My husband uses this for his military haircuts, and I was leary about using it for anything else. However, our baby has gotten a bald spot on the back of his head, and is only a few months old, and I didn't want to take him to a barber yet. I used these by myself, with the baby on my lap. Because his hair is very fine, this took about 10 minutes to cut the top to about an inch and the sides to about 1/2 inch. His hair looks a lot better, and because you don't need to worry about the clippers being a certain angle to cut, he was very happy throughout the haircut. I had to shake the clippers a few times because his fine hair got stuck in the guard, but it was a million times easier than worrying about scissors or a stranger with clippers on a baby with no motor skills. The haircut looks professional (when my husband got home, he said 'looks like you took him to the barber'). Very very easy to use, doesn't take skill, just make sure that you use the combs with the guard that goes across the bottom in places and not the one that is open at the bottom. Would recommend to everyone who wants to cut their baby's hair, or anyone who wants to do their own short cuts. Do not know about cutting adult regular cuts, because that's not what we've used it for. Added on 3/15/2011: Once the batteries have been charged a few times, there is no way to keep a charge. You can plug it in constantly when not being used, but they will die after only a couple minutes. Had to eventually throw them away. Too bad.
  490. Works best with soft dry hair. Helps to use a hand mirror to view the back. The user needs to develop some manual dexterity. If you wear your hair short it's worth the price. Like all clippers without an attached vacuum it leaves a mess to clean up.
  491. This is the easiest and fastest hair cutting product I have ever used. In 2 minutes you are done!
  492. This clipper is the answer to an even cut every time! It travels with me so that I can have that fresh cut any time.

  494. After going through the initial hair loss and thinning process, my hair was beginning to look like a birds nest (depending on which way the wind happened to be blowing). So, I decided to keep it short. Incidentally, I have a flowbee that I bought back in 1996 and it still works great!! I bought this little guy for something portable, quick, and not requiring a great deal of effort to setup. I Love It! I take it outside and it takes about ten minutes. It gives me a very neat cut and If you have someone that can trim behind your ears and the back of your neck... you just can't get a better haircut. You'll certainly save some bucks on barber visits. Two months now and it is holding up fine. It says you can rinse it under running water to clean out the hair, but I didn't feel comfortable with that so I blew it out with my compressor, and then gave it a light oiling after each use. But if you use it once a week or so, you don't get much hair in it and you can just blow it out by mouth... then oil. I'm sure I will eventually wear it out, but I'll gladly buy another.
  495. If you want to keep a short haircut in great condition this is the machine to do it easily and very conveniently. I think that I might have received a good one out of the bunch rather than the normal crap I am used to getting :o)Still love it and would highly recommend one to buyers except for those that have very thin hair. Not thin as in balding hair but literally thin (diameter) hair. We tried using this thing on a friend that has very thin hair and it did not cut it very well.   496. First cut was okay second cut was just okay third use put a big bald spot right by my ear. I'm still getting used to it maybe I'll get better but the back and forth side to side is how it happened so I'll be careful when I make those moves from now on.
  497. UPDATE: I discovered that the small oil bottle make all the difference in keeping the Remington SCC-100 Clipper going when it starts slowing down. It only takes a couple drops, and it will keep going for several weeks more. Just keep doing this, and your clipper should last for many years. Funny this though--Remington did not tell me this when I telephoned them to complain about their product. You don't have to keep buy new one after new one. JUST USE THE OIL THAT WAS PROVIDED WITH YOUR CLIPPER. I have to say I think it is a good product for a short haircut. However, the battery will not hold a charge for any length of time for it to be useful. Worst of all, this particular clipper is designed so it will NOT operate while plugged into an electrical outlet. This clipper is a perfect example of how today’s manufacturers take advantage of the buying public. Instead of producing a product that will last at least a few years, they make the product so it will FAIL to operate within a few months. Great job, Remington--you excel in cheating your customers! As for myself, I will never buy this product again, and I encourage other people to do the same!

  521. I was hesitant to buy this, after reading some of the reviews posted here, but I'm glad I took a chance on it. This little trimmer is worth its weight in gold!   522. I have never written a review before but what I discovered with this clipper made me want to let all of you know who have had problems with what seemed like the battery. I have used this for about 16 months and then the same thing happened to me. It seemed like the battery stopped holding a charge and it just stopped working. I was so disappointed because I love this product and I use it a lot and I really couldn't believe this was the problem even after everyone had said they had the same issue with it.<br /><br />I read through many reviews on Remington's website and they never acknowledged that their product had a battery problem despite all the negative reviews (they would respond to each negative review telling the customer to contact customer service). Then I found this post on the website (the picture I posted). Remington said it is recommended to oil the blades for optimum performance. I added some olive oil (any household oil will work) to the blades and it worked like the first time I charged it!! I couldn't believe it! All it needed was some oil and the blades started moving again.<br /><br />I gave this product four stars because when it works it works very well but you just have to keep up the maintenance on it. I hope this helps most of you solve your problem and you won't have to keep buying new ones every few months. A couple people also mentioned something about cleaning out the blades because they might be clogged, so if the oil doesn't work then maybe that might be a solution for you as well.

  526. The cutter gives a nice even trim. The problem is that not all head surfaces are curved, so it sometimes takes a little work to find a good cutting angle. The comb comes from the factory with sharp teeth that ride directly against the scalp, so I would recommend trying another product if your scalp is sensitive, like mine. The sensation is like being scratched by a wire brush. The on/off switch is easily activated by pressure, so this may not be good for travel as it would be predictably easy to be turned on in your suitcase.

  530. I am a gadget guy, I like to try new inovative products. When I saw this in Popular Science mag, I just had to try it. I have kept my hair short for a few years now, and was always looking for a better way to cut it, besides just a regular pair of electric clippers. The product does cut already short hair quite well. It you have longer hair, and are looking to go with a short cut, then you will have to get buzzed with a regular electric clipper first, then maintain with the Short Cut clipper. To see how good it cut, I let my hair grow out to about 3/4\\" to 1\\" in length. The clipper has a dial that adjusts the comb that controls the length. It goes from 1, 1 1/2, 2, 3, 4 (specific length for these dial settings are in the manual). I started out with 4, and it was just bairly touching my hair, so I switched it down to a 3, and it just started trimming my hair, so I then dialed it down to a 2, and it was the right length for me. It took several passes to get all of the hair cut, and it does create a very fine cut, so make sure you use it in an area that is easy to clean. I use mine in the shower, then take a shower right after to keep the mess under control. Overall, I would say this clipper is quite good, but it would be best to use it about once a week to help maintain your length.
  531. I am always on the lookout for an easier way to shave my own head. I go close to bald (#1 setting or less) and using regular old clippers takes about 20 minutes and a lot of going over the same spots. I was hoping this would be \\"as easy to use as a brush\\" (as the ad says). It WAS easy to use. Unfortunately, it had a couple big flaws. Flaw #1: Side of the Head Shaving. The curved blade that is so nice for the back and top of the head is useless on the side of your head just above the ears. This is the most important area for me to shave down because hair over my ears drives me crazy. Think about how a curved blade is supposed to get that area. It can't go vertical because your ear is in the way. It can't go horizontal because my head isn't rounded there. Maybe my head is the wrong shape, but it didn't work for me. Flaw #2: \\"Tracks\\". If you've used a clipper before, you've probably seen the comb tracks left behind when using an attachment. Usually, I go over the tracks in different directions to even everything out. I could not get rid of the tracks using this Clipper. I looked like my head was striped! Maybe if I shaved to the lowest setting the tracks would go away? So, after having two flaws that made these clippers basically useless to me, why three-stars? Because they work if you are looking for a longer cut. I used this at the \\"2\\" setting on my son and it cleaned him up nicely. The design and ease of use are really nice - I just wish it worked better on me. BOTTOM LINE: If you're looking to clean up some straggling hairs on a longer crew/buzz cut - this could be the tool for you. Using it like a brush is a real time saver. If you're looking to go real short, I would have to recommend you stick with a traditional clipper (such as [[ASIN:B000MND29Q Conair HCT475 Rechargeable Cord/Cordless Pro Style Kit, 24 Piece]] ). I always end up using them to clean up after failed attempts with other clippers/razors.
  532. I've been using this product for the past three months, and I couldn't be more pleased. It produces the same quality haircut as the barber shop, and it's as quick and convenient as shaving.<br /><br />I have to admit, I did not have high expectations when I ordered this product from Amazon. After it arrived, it took me another month to work up the courage to use it. Finally, on the first day of my vacation, when I knew I would have time to grow out my hair a bit if the clipper made a mess of things, I took the plunge.<br /><br />It turns out that the clipper is incredibly easy to use. Because of the curved design and bidirectional cutters, the optimal motion is very similar to shaving. You just \\"comb\\" the clipper back and forth around your head until you've covered all areas. It's amazingly simple and produces very even results. You can literally use it with your eyes closed.<br /><br />I have not had the problem noted by another reviewer of clogged blades. I keep my hair trimmed short (about 1/4 inch, or the No. 2 comb on a traditional hair clipper), and the short hairs just fall away. I suspect that this trimmer is really only suitable for short hair.<br /><br />Two issues you should note, though:<br />1) The trimmer comes from the factory with the balding comb attached. You need to pop it off and replace it with the comb that let's you set hair length. This is a silly way to ship the clipper -- unless you read the instructions carefully, you might miss this important detail and end up with an essentially shaved head. Remington should ship it with the safer comb and let you switch to the balding comb.<br />2) The trimmer doesn't have a battery gauge like many shavers, and it cannot run directly off AC power (it won't turn on when plugged into the charger). This can be inconvenient if the trimmer runs out of power half way through a haircut. I've made it a habit to charge the trimmer once a month whether it needs it or not. A batter gauge would be nice. [Update 19 March 2011: The clipper is now about 2 1/2 years old, and the batteries don't seem to hold a charge as well any more. The clipper still works fine, but now I need to charge it after every use, or the battery dies half way through the next haircut. I wish the batteries were replaceable. I bought another one last month in case the batteries on the original fail completely.]<br /><br />Bottom line: This clipper has exceeded my expectations. It allows me to cut my own (admittedly short) hair at home as easily as shaving, rather than having to make trips to the barber shop. It has already paid for itself, let's me cut my hair more frequently (and therefore avoid the \\"hey, you got your hair cut\\" syndrome when I'd let it get too long before cutting), and is super convenient. What a nice surprise.s now about 2 1/2 years old, and the batteries don't seem to hold a charge as well any more. The clipper still works fine, but now I need to charge it after every use, or the battery dies half way through the next haircut. I wish the batteries were replaceable. I bought another one last month in case the batteries on the original fail completely.] Bottom line: This clipper has exceeded my expectations. It allows me to cut my own (admittedly short) hair at home as easily as shaving, rather than having to make trips to the barber shop. It has already paid for itself, let's me cut my hair more frequently (and therefore avoid the \\"hey, you got your hair cut\\" syndrome when I'd let it get too long before cutting), and is super convenient. What a nice surprise.

  537. I used this for about a year and a half and it stopped holding a charge long enough to finish a haircut and it is not user replaceable. For the price, you could replace it once a year and beat going to a barber, but I just switched to a regular corded trimmer when it stopped holding a charge.<br /><br />-------------<br />After hitting the barber every 2 weeks to get my hair shaved down to 1 guard, I bought a pair of regular clippers and had my wife cut my hair for about 6 months. This paid for itself after a couple of haircuts, but coordinating time for her to do it proved to be harder than just going to the barber. I ordered this Remington Clipper and am able to do it myself pretty easily.<br /><br />My hair is thinning and I use this on the shortest setting. If my hairstyle was any more complicated, I don't think I'd be brave enough to try it with this device, but if you're reading this, you're probably in the same boat. For this application, it works great.<br /><br />The first time I used this, it didn't look that good and my wife had to help me touch it up. By the third time, I was able to do it on my own without any help. It takes a little practice of following the contour of your head in a few areas like above the ears, but once you get it down, it is easy. I'd recommend keeping a hand mirror to check the back of your head, though, as it is easy to miss spots if you can't see back there.<br /><br />My only complaint is that it feels a little flimsy. It does not feel as solid as the traditional clippers I bought at around the same price as it is entirely plastic other than the cutting blade. There's something in it that rattles if I shake it.<br /><br />If it breaks, I'd buy a new one right away, which is always a strong recommendation for a product. (I'm hoping they'll still be making them by that point.)<br /><br />I haven't had any problem with the charging. I usually throw it on the charger after I use it and it still has enough charge to cutmy hair the next time I use it. (I've only had it a couple of months, so the battery life will probably diminish over time.)<br />------------------<br />After about 18 months of using this, the (non-replaceable) battery stopped holding a charge long enough for a full haircut and I retired it and went back to a regular corded trimmer. Nice product, but not for the long haul.
  538. Good, not great, cut is not as even as at your barber. For the price it is great deal. Hopefully will last a long time.

  540. We bought this for my son who is in ROTC and clips his hair very short. (Thus use of the product has always been to maintain this short cut, not to achieve it from a full head of hair.) Theoretically the product has a 4-year warranty so we'll see whether Remington stands behind their product.   541. I had my hair cut really short by my barber about 3 weeks ago, and bought this product to maintain the length and shape of my hair. It was SOOOOO easy to use this product and shave my hair down to the nub. The my long-haired 6-year-old wanted me to do his head - it came out terrific!! The battery lasted for both hair cuts - about 15-20 minutes on the first charge. This clipper will make maintaining the length of my hair a real snap. This product is very ergonomic and easy to hold and the curved blade area contours it the head perfectly. The pop-out trimmer works great around the ears.<br /><br />The price I paid for these clippers ($31) has already paid for itself when you consider (2) haircuts would have cost me $34 plus tip. I don't think my barber, Ray B., is going to be very happy about this. Lol....<br /><br />I have already recommended this to other people, and once you try these clippers you will also recommend it to others. If I could, I would give these clippers 6 stars!! :-)
  542. This thing works great, but you have to keep it cleaned or it will appear to have a dead battery. Use the brush and/or squirt water inside it. If there's hair inside (that you might not even be able to see), it'll stop working, and then you'll blame the battery.
  543. still using it after a few years. great product although the battery no longer holds charge like it used to. I have to recharge it prior to each use and you cant use it for too long after each charge.
  544. This works great. The hair get caught in the guides. Runs for a long time. But once its ready to die, theres no notice, just shuts off.

  554. This is by far the easiest trimmer I've ever owned. If you can use a comb, you can give yourself a very nice cut. Takes me about 5 minutes to give myself a high and tight.<br /><br />It does take a little experimentation to figure out how to set the guides, but it really is pretty straight forward. The only thing I would recommend is that you also have something like a beard trimmer to get behind you ears and around the nape of the neck. According to the manual it takes 8 hours to charge and only cuts for 15 minutes, but in my experience it only takes about 3 to charge and lasts around a half hour.<br /><br />I have not experienced any of the battery problems that others have reported, and even if I did I would order another one as it paid for itself within the first two uses.

  556. Easily the best clipper I've owned. Easiest to use and softest on the head. The curved portion really helps in making it easy to use every 3 days
  557. I haven't had any jams or problems at all with the unit. The first time, I got a so-so cut with it. Getting used to it, I &#34;understand&#34; I need to go back and forth more times than I did with the one I replaced, but once I did that it gets a pretty even cut. Remember to knock out hair from the combs to keep it working well as you cut. A couple cuts later and I figure I'm way ahead $$$ already. Much faster to use this than a flowbee (I've been cutting my own hair for decades) and can touch up my buzzcut in the shower stall (dry/no water) in minutes with no big mess to put away. I touch up at least once a week and it works for me. Couldn't really ask for more for the device it is. Still would have room to buy &#34;the perfect&#34; device, if I could figure out what that would be. If it broke today, I'd buy another. How's that for an &#34;I'd buy again&#34; recommendation? :)

As the ad states, it cuts in both directions, is elf-sharpening, is easily adjustable via the dial on the handle and can be rinsed under the tap when done. It charges quickly and holds a charge for weeks at a time. I highly recommend these clippers.

  569. I got this to start cutting my own hair. With three kids and a wife all getting haircuts this really helps stretch out the budget. The nice thing is I can touch up my hair every week. Before I was trying to stretch out trips to the barber shop and my hair was always going from short to shaggy between visits. I find that the #4 and #3 work well for a nice business looking haircut. I then feather the edges with the #2 setting.<br /><br />Design:<br />Fits nice in your hand. The curved cutter is a cleaver design. Overall you can tell that this was designed for self-cutting of one's hair. The recharge feature is great. With no cord I can cut my hair standing in the shower (no water) so I don't make a mess.<br /><br />Price:<br />Five stars for price! This gadget pays for itself in a few weeks.<br /><br />Maintenance:<br />So far it has worked with little fuss. I do put a few drops of oil (included) on the blades before I use it.<br /><br />Tips:<br />Go against the grain of your hair so the hairs will stand up to get trimmed. I find short strokes work better then trying to use it like a comb. The spots above my ears are the most challenging. I fold my ear down then go up with the trimmer.<br /><br />Overall I going to give it 5 stars. Again, the fifth star is for price.
  570. The longer comb attachment tends to &#34;knock over&#34; my hair. But I have been having good results with the following: I take the guide completely off the trimmer to leave the cutting blades exposed, then hold it at both ends with two hands and a finger on each hand providing a depth gauge. Then I can use it to &#34;sweep&#34; over my hair at that predetermined height using both hands and the exposed cutting blades having direct access to each hair without its being pushed over by the comb attachment, giving a perfectly even cut.<br /><br />I am considering modifying the longer of the comb attachments by cutting off all of the comb teeth in the middle (probably using a dremel tool) , leaving only the teeth on the ends as depth guides. But so far the two handed technique described above does very well at cutting my wavy/curly hair to one inch or one and a half inches, whereas the comb attachment tends to 'knock over' my hair causing an uneven cut.<br /><br />A decent tool that works very well for me now that I've learned its nature and modified its use a bit to my needs. I was considering upping my game to a FlowBee or something similar but now that I've learned this new method I think the Short Cut will work fine.<br /><br />And when the battery dies I plan on cutting the device apart and either installing a new battery or a tether for an external battery. (JB weld is your friend for reassembly. )<br /><br />I foresee this giving me years upon years of convenient use.<br /><br />**absolutely essential to brush this clean and lube it after every time, or even once or twice during a cut. It helps preserve the blades and also keeps the running speed up. I use WD40, Singer sewing machine oil, or anything else that I have around**

  579. First off, let me state I've had this item for over a year. I was hesitant on buying it because of the reviews that said the battery didn't last very long. I noticed the same thing with mine after using it 3-4 times, but the thing is, its not the battery. Its the blades, they need to be oiled after almost every use. The blades on this thing are huge, way bigger than your average clipper. As such, they need to be oiled more frequently. It DOES sound like the battery is going dead, even after a charge. But for me, 3-4 drops of oil on the blades, and it sounded better than new. Most people never oil their clippers and get away with it. With this product, you cant. It comes with oil, use it, you will notice a difference. For the last time, its not the battery. Use the brush it came with, use the oil, and you will love this product!
  580. Safe & easy to use. I use on the lowest setting & don't have to take the time to go to the barber shop. Pays for itself in one month.
  581. Had been cutting my hair at about a half inch with a Wahl clipper set and hated it. The clip on guide was a pain and the mess usually resulted in waiting until I was really shaggy before I cut again. The Short Cut is so easy to use that I have found about 5 minutes once a week keeps my hair just the way I want it. Very little clean up and really easy to use. I have had the unit 3 months and so far no problem. I use the guide comb to trim my hair and then switch to the bald comb for the back of my neck. The pop up trimmer works to trim sideburns and around the ears but I still prefer a small battery powered clipper type trimmer for around my ears. The wide curved blade does a great job and I would recommend this to anyone who wants to keep their hair cut short. FOLLOW UP COMMENT Aug.17, 2015 I have had the short cut for almost two years and just cut my hair this morning. It still works great, no problem with the battery. I would still recommend the short cut to anyone who wants to save some money by cutting their own hair.

  588. It has it's flaws. First off, they should have made it with the option of using it with a cordless or corded feature.<br /><br />Secondly, even though it stops midway through the haircut, and having to restart it again and again, and not by the on/off switch, but with a screwdriver along side the blades where you need to give it a little extra push to get it going again, because the on/off switch is just not enough to get it going.<br /><br />Third, many times when it detects a load, meaning when it's going through hair that has not been cut in a week or two, it stops, and you will have to use a screwdriver like I do to get it going again. Cutting my hair which is short normally takes me an hour now, whereas it took 10-12 minutes before is to say the least a real effort on my part. Cutting your hair with this takes perserverence, and a slow to blow temper. This means no coffee, or caffeine, definitely no energy shots, when using this trimmer.<br /><br />Having it be just shy of having a goat chew on my head to trim it all down to where it looks acceptable to me, this is the best thing out on the market today.<br /><br />In closing, I do see my old barber from time to time, and even he thinks it would be advantageous to stay with the shortcut as it does do a nice job.   590. When you receive your clippers plug it in and insure that it charges at least 24 hours minimum. When using the trimmer insure that it is fully extended and clips into place. Now that the two little mishaps that I experienced are out of the way I would like to say that for a close hair cut where no tapering is needed or required they worked very well. Just run the clippers over your head several times in different directions going back and forth and you will achieve the length of cut selected on the adjustment dial. The clippers work well for trimming up the perimeter of the hair but I found it very beneficial to have someone else trim across the back of the neck as it is difficult to achieve an even cut doing it by yourself in this area. The clippers worked well and were easy to clean and lubricate with the enclosed bottle of oil. I purchased a second for my grandson who also wears his hair short but his mother does the clipping for him.
  591. I first used this it seemed okay. Than I started looking at my hair. Looked like corn rows or something. I had streaks of hair longer than the other. Than on one side above the ear you I saw 3 or 4 inch streak that was shorter than the rest. It was the length of the clipper. So if you are using don't push down to hard. Let it glide. The first time I must have pushed down. Second time I cut my hair I let it glide by it self. It did okay. Well it quit working. Work for 5-10 seconds and just cut off.   592. I've been cutting my own hair for well over a decade now, ever since it started receding and I decided that paying someone [...] bucks a month to cut it was foolish. I started with a Flowbee, but it just doesn't cut short enough (the more I lose, the shorter I want it). I then got a regular Remington home hair cutting kit which served me well for about 7 years, but again I wanted to go shorter. Then I saw the Short Cut as a Gold Box deal, read the description about doing a bald cut, and I knew I had to try it. Am I ever glad I did. This is the fastest, easiest, most worry-free clippers I have ever used. I used to have my wife inspect my head after cutting because I inevitably missed a spot, but because of the bi-directional cutting it is easy to get every last hair. I love the bald cut, and because it is so quick to maintain after the first time, I can cut my hair in minutes, a couple times a week, with minimal clean up. My only complaint is that you cannot use it corded when the battery gets low, but that is a minor inconvenience. I would recommend this clipper to anyone who likes to keep their hair short (there is a longer length comb included) with minimal fuss and repeatable results.
  593. The Good:<br />1)On the 3/16\\" setting, hair is very even (your results may vary).<br />2)Quick.<br /><br />The Bad:<br />1)Very Poor quality control. The \\"charging\\" indicator light died after a week.<br />2)Poor Ergonomics-the on/off switch is under the palm of your hand.   594. The Good: I like how short my hair is with this clipper on it's lowest setting. When I'm finished, I have a pretty even cut. The Bad: The bent blade is good because it cuts fast, but bad because it's difficult to cut the areas around the ear. The Ugly: The red light which is supposed to indicate the battery almost being dead comes on about 5 seconds before the device is dead. This thing takes HOURS (as in about 36, the charging light goes off) to charge fully, and it will not stay charged between haircuts.(say a period of 3 weeks) Each time I attempt to cut my hair, the buzzer inevitably dies leaving me with half a shaved head and 2 hours to kill while I hope I can get enough juice to finish my hair. The buzzer will not operate even when plugged into the wall once it's out of battery, which is just crap given it is designed to give hair cuts. Even when I'm cutting 1/8th inch of hair off, the buzzer clogs time and time and time again. I have to move the combs forward and dump the hair each time I make a cut. All in all, I would throw this thing away if I didn't like how short it cuts my hair. 1/8th\\" clips of a regular buzzer go nowhere near as short. I just might anyway, because as I type this I'm sitting here with a half shaved head, waiting for the POS to charge.

  596. Love it! The slogan really is true; \\"You can't mess this up!\\" I bought one for myself about a year ago and just bought another as a gift. You literally hold it like a hairbrush and draw it across your hair as though you were brushing it. Even the back comes out looking great without a hand mirror. The only minor flaw I've noted is that, even on a full charge, the unit will hesitate a bit on start-up, as though the batteries were about to die; however it does continue to work and after a minute or so it goes full steam. Also, it does need to be charged before use -it will not run just by plugging it in. I use my clipper weekly to keep a fresh cut look and it paid for itself (versus going to a barber) in less than 2 months. Also, the Amazon price is the best I've found - even less than when I bought my first one elsewhere.
  597. I have this trimmer/clipper for some of the same reasons mentioned... I have almost no hair on top but pleanty on the sides. I would go to get my hair cut and just get a 2 1/2 all over which suited me fine but it cost me the same as someone with a full head of hair.   598. I basically agree with many of the more recent reviews and will just add my take. This product is really designed for a person to use on themselves in maintaining a very short close cut hairstyle. If you are buying this to do summer \\"crew cuts\\" for your kids or often let you hair grow longer and then cut it short occasionally, I would not recommend this item. You should buy a more traditional clipper as it does not have the power to cut longer or thicker hair. Here are my cons. - The motor is not super powerful and it really needs a full charge to work well. - The clipper will not run while plugged in and it takes a long time to charge, so plan ahead. - If you hair is a little longer than usual, start out at a higher setting and work your way down to your usual setting. - The pop out sideburn trimmer is really not that useful. It doesn't cut around the ears very well, in my opinion. I use the one on my cordless shaver to do the ears and sideburns. All that said, if you have short, thin hair and simply want to maintain a close cut hairstyle yourself, then this is much easier to use than a traditional clipper as it fits nicely in your hand and is basically like combing your hair. It also makes it much easier to do the back of your head and neck area yourself.

  601. This device is much better than using a more conventional trimmer. It makes little touchups a casual thing--'oh, I'm a little uneven on the left--zip-zip--done.' Nope, it's all the same length. Maybe there's a way, but I'm too klutzy to get it to work. Edit 10/8/2011: a year after I bought it, the battery conked out on me. No more charge.   602. I've been using the Remington Short Cut Clipper for about a month now. I like to keep my hair reasonably short (#3 clipper)and, like others, was not happy paying about $15 a month for a 5-minute haircut. Now I just give my hair a weekly quick cut with the Remington. I take it slow and easy and make sure to keep the clipper at the proper angle. No problems, no \\"chunks\\" gouged, no bald spots that nature hasn't given me. The only complaint I have (and the reason I deducted a star) is that the clipper's pop-up trimmer hasn't worked very well for me so I've been using either scissors or the pop-up trimmer on my Norelco shaver for trimming around the ears. I probably would not recommend this clipper to those who keep their hair long or for those who want more complicated haircuts, but for my simple needs the Remington Short Cut Clipper has worked very well.
  603. The curve does not fit every head. In fact No one could get a good haircut from it.
  604. I want to add a point that I did not see a lot in the reviews: This product is doing great job too when you want to keep long hair!!! I'm the alive proof and I'm impressed about how it was easy to get a decent long cut, let says about one to three inches for me depending of the location; I mean you can also handle the ShortCut clipper to have longer hair in front and shorter in the back of the head. To realize a long cut, just keep the ShortCut clipper at the end of the hair (not on skull) to remove just some hair and repeat until you have removed what you want. I'm sorry Remington but you will have to rename your clipper \\"Short/medium clipper\\". Like a lot of people said, I was tired of going to spend time and money to the barber and I was looking for a traditional clipper but I was not ready to cut my hair very short as you know like ¼ inch or something like that. Then I saw the short cut clipper. But Remington never said in their documentation that their product was able keep hair longer than ½ inch. More over, reviewers at Amazon did not really talked about that possibility since a lot of people just want short hair if not skin head! I saw that some people complained about the long battery charge but I'm really not afraid about that. The battery had enough power to do my first hair cut and after a few hours of charge, I remove some more hair to do a perfect job but I'm sure after some practices, one full charge will be enough. I think Remington choose a smaller adaptor with lower milliamperes to extend the battery life to a maximum. So I want to highly recommend this product not only for short cut hair but also for people just wanting to remove some hair.
  605. Excellent cutting ability and fast to use.
  606. I really enjoyed using this short cut clipper. It was the easiest equipment to cut my hair and avoid wire managament with other brands. However, the battery charger is really noise and it takes hours to have full charge.   607. This clipper sounds good in theory, being curved to match your head, but unless your head is perfectly round and of the same radius as the curvature of the clipper then it will give an uneven cut. My head has high spots and low spots, and this clipper couldn't reach into the low spots.

I have really thick hair and have noticed that I have to keep running through the same area a few times to make sure there are no loose length hairs that was missed the first time around. A negative is that the plastic clips can be very pressure sensitive and bends easily. The charge holds for a while though and that's a plus for me.

  617.   623. Mine died after using it a few times over a period of 6 months or so...I had let it sit for a while and it wouldn't take a charge. I'm experienced at replacing rechargeable batteries in these types of devices though and gave this one a shot. It turned out to be the most difficult battery replacement yet for me - very odd design. After several hours soldering in new rechargeable batteries, I put it back together....and it was still dead. It seems like a great design, externally, if only they had put good quality batteries and a good charging circuit. Obviously, from the many reviews you will find here, Remington put the crappiest, cheapest batteries in it they could find in the supply chain. That's fine if you make them replaceable...this obviously is not. Also, whatever charging circuit they designed doesn't cut it.

  630. I am writing this review on the occasion of buying my second clipper.<br /><br />I'm buying it again, which speaks to my satisfaction with the product. It works well, is easy to use, and I enjoy the ease of being able to cut my own hair without constantly asking my wife to spot-check the back of my head for areas I missed with the smaller clippers.<br /><br />However, I bought my last one Sept 2008. It didn't last very long. In my case, the power supply failed internally. The rechargeable battery isn't replaceable or accessible. This item is certainly designed for early failure/replacement with regular use. So long as you aren't expecting years of reliable use from this product, you'll be satisfied. And at $35, it isn't priced to be an heirloom.<br /><br />Update:<br /><br />On my fourth one now, and I have found that I can extend the life by being very careful to re-oil the blades after every use. Not sure how this is related. Perhaps more regularly oiled blades reduce engine strain and subsequently wear and tear on power system.... Still very happy with how it cuts.
  631. Exactly what I expected, and gives me the haircut I used to pay $20 for at the barbershop. Right on.
  632. I was skeptical of whether this thing would work, as the other reviews raised the possibility of battery problems, the product having been discontinued, etc. Having just given myself a haircut (albeit a very short one) for the first time in my life, I must say I am impressed. I charged it over night, and this ingenious little clipper performed as advertised. It takes a few passes and you need a mirror to ensure that you don't miss a spot, but the resulting cut was nice and even. I did not experience any pulling or tugging at my hair, but perhaps that is because I moved it slowly over my head per the instructions. (for reference, I have very straight hair, so maybe that contributed to my success) I can't speak with regard to durability, but it appears to be solidly built and soundly designed. Given that I used to shell out $12+ per haircut, this will save me time and money even if I only use it a few times.
  633. Three years ago I went from short hair 'business' hair style to #3/2 buzz cut. To keep up appearances, I spent $10+2 x 2 monthly. Once I tried this clipper, I was able to keep my buzz cut trimmed out once a week and it paid for itself in 30 days. My original product recently showed battery recharge problems and although it is no longer easily found in local drugstores, I purchased a 2nd online and am very happy with it. I'm surprised that Remington hasn't improved distribution in these times of short hair and limited budgets for the user demographic.

Why it isn't on the upper side instead of the back for easier thumb control should be rethought.   670. Seems to do the actual cutting okay, however, this unit has serious problems with the internal charger. And it takes about a day or more to fully recharge.
  671. After getting the clippers, I was extremely excited to find a foolproof way to trim my boyfriend's hair or even he could do it himself. Unfortunately, the first couple times using this device has been a bit of a miniature disaster ending in discomfort, hair-pulling, uneven overall cut, and bald spots. These clippers are not recommended for those with thick, curly hair. The arrangement or even the sharpness of the blades make it useless if not dangerous for said persons. The only pros I can think of are the slim, compact look of the clipper and how it indeed offers various settings to toy with. I think that it is a bargain. Additionally, it is RELATIVELY easy to clean the hair from the clippers themselves. However, cleaning after yourself when this thing flings hair all over your bathroom floor is a different story. The other cons unrelated to hair types are the battery life and the quality of the parts. The battery life is extremely short. It takes hours to fully charge. Once charged, hope to God that you have hands quicker than lightning or you may end up with half your hair untrimmed. Secondly, the parts that it comes with are thin and flimsy. I have not broken anything yet but you must be extra gentle when cleaning the clippers because the guide bars are made of very flimsy plastic. You must pull very hard to get it out to clean and each time I wince because I think it'll snap in half. I think they should have stuck with a more sturdy material. Lastly, the contour of the clippers leaves some areas of hair longer than others. Areas of concern are on the sides right above the ears. It must be complemented with other clippers. I probably won't buy this again for anyone but it was a nice concept that needs some development.
  672. Pros: 1. The curve design is fine; makes it easy to get an even cut. 2. Light weight and very portable, easy to hold. Cons: 1. Switch is in a bad location. Fred, Milford, N. J.

  677. I purchased the Remington Short Cut as a simple means to cut my hair. Before I used it, I watched the instructional video and some people posted videos on you-tube, with their personal experiences.<br /><br />Normally, I use the number 1 setting, which I believe is 3.2 MM, when I cut my hair with the traditional hair clippers. This has a number one setting, which according to the instructions is right around the same length as the traditional hair clippers.<br /><br />This has some postives and some negatives.<br />Here's the positives,<br />-Its easy to use, and its works very quickly.<br />-Its lightweight and fits comfortably in the palm of your hand<br />-The curved structure fits the shape of your head, and your able to access the hard to reach places.<br /><br />When I was cutting my hair, it didn't seem like it was actually taking hair off, but when I was finished I can see the difference.<br /><br />The negatives,<br />-It seems like when you get done cutting your hair, you have to use the traditional hair clippers to &#34;clean it up&#34; sort of speak.<br />-I noticed in a you tube video the gentleman who used the product appeared to have the same problem, and he had to use the traditional clippers to shape it, even it out.<br /><br />My feeling is, if I have to use the traditional clippers to even it out, than I can just use the traditional clippers for the entire haircut.<br /><br />I'll try it again to see if maybe the more I get used to it, the less likely I would have to revert to the traditional clippers to finish the haircut.<br /><br />Until then, I would say this is average at best.

  688. I got this as a gift at Christmas.<br />I really like how easy this is to use.<br />Be careful you set it on the right setting or you'll have no hair.<br />It is great for fast touch-ups
  689. I've read the reports of short battery life, but I found that you just need to OIL THE BLADES! Makes sense that this trimmer would slow down and stop without oil because the blades are, at least, twice as long as any other trimmer product. I could be wrong and there could be a battery problem, but I doubt it.<br />That being said, I have find this is the best trimmer I have used for the whole-head: Both hair and beard. I have a box of 10 or more trimmers that all work about the same more or less. This is a better design. You have to be a little creative to figure out how to position it around the temples to get close, but everywhere else THE LONG CURVED BLADES GIVE A VERY EVEN AND FAST CUT. Especially on the head where there are dips. The usual 1.5 inch wide trimmers cut down into the dips in the back of the head and the cut always looks uneven. This 3 inch wide blade evens out the dips by not cutting down into them. It makes a much better looking finish. It is also faster because it cuts twice as wide in one pass. After every cut brush it off and OIL it and plug it into the charger.
  690. Ordered the clipper for my Dad's birthday. He is absolutely happy that he doesn't have to go to the hairdresser anymore.<br />It works great. I just ordered another one for my brother.<br />Would recommend it anytime. Shipping time was really quick too.<br />Thank you
  691. This is a great product for someone who wants to be &#34;almost bald&#34; - not quite Mr. Clean level, but pretty close. That said, I have to rebuy it about once a year because the battery won't hold a charge and it's difficult to clean.

  698. This is a great product and the only one I know of that allows you to shave your own head this easily. I use this once a week to keep my hair buzzed short and it takes maybe 5 to 10 minutes each time. You basically use it like a comb in long strokes. After many, many months of use, one of the plastic clips came lose after cleaning it, but it didn't impair function, particularly after placing the guide back on (I use the shaver on its lowest possible setting for the closest possible cut--I still have a full head of hair, but it looks better and is easier to manager closely cut). Frankly, for as little as this costs, I don't mind buying a new shaver once a year or so.
  699. This is my second Shortcut. I bought one right when they were first released and I've been pretty pleased with it. It makes getting my hair cut down to near nothing a breeze compared to using traditional clippers.<br /><br />Fair warning, I use it with the balding comb and set the guard to it's lowest height. The result is equivalent to about 2 days after shaving my head with a razor; longer than day-old stubble, but not much.<br /><br />The Shortcut makes it easy to get my hair cut evenly so I don't miss patches like I've done before with traditional clippers.<br /><br />If you have really thick hair, or let it grow too long the Shortcut may not be the best tool to knock it down. I've had a few times where I needed to buzz my hair first with clippers and then clean it up with the Shortcut. When I go more than 2 or 3 weeks between trims is when this is needed most. Otherwise I try to clip my hair weekly or every 2 weeks and the Shortcut works great for that.<br /><br />My beef is that you can't use this while plugged in. So if the battery is dead you're not getting a cut. Also the battery doesn't last very long. Mine will now only hold a ~10 minute charge and it's obvious that it's not running the motor nearly as powerfully as when it was new. I'm going to hack my original Shortcut now that I have the new one and see if I can bypass the charging safety circuit so it can be used plugged in.<br /><br />Despite the battery problems, I like this tool. Even if I have to buy one yearly, that's a heck of a lot less than paying for a haircut every 4 to 6 weeks.
  700. This product is perfect if you want to get a close shave without using a razor. The cordless feature makes this product perfect for using it outside which pleases my wife becuase the clipped hair stays out of the house!
  701. This is the second Remington Short Cut I've owned. The first one failed due to my carelessness. Admittedly, it can be a little messy with the clippings but the results achieved are well worth it. I've always maintained a crew cut which this instrument is perfectly suited. I have purchased two as gifts and the recipients have been as pleased with the results of their hair cuts as I have with mine. It pays for itself after just a couple of trims.
  702. My husband uses this every other week. He does keep his hair as short as possible. THis is his second one and the first lasted for years.
  703. I love the design! But it has poor battery life will eventually die completely, and cannot work corded. It's another one of those great designs screwed-up by making them with substandard Chinese quality.
  704. I've never written a review before, but this item was bad enough that I don't want anyone else to buy it without knowing that it simply isn't powerful enough to cut hair. I have thick hair, but it's not abnormally thick. It's average. I fully charged the clipper and started cutting. You can hear the blades physically slow when they come into contact with your hair. You brush back and forth, pull it away to have a look--and there's hardly any hair there. Nothing has been cut off. I've used many different clippers before, but I've never come across one this weak.
  705. This product does not cut your hair even. The shape of the product is highly dependent on the shape of your head, and if it is not close, you have your work cut out for you! I like the rechargeable battery though...
  706. the charge is so good. it hold over night and i am wright thing this review a year later form the day i got it. its still work as good as the day i bought it. I used this on my self and my pets. well on pets its great because of no cord. but not good on the clips. if you need a bald shave work best for dogs and humans. i told a few of my co-workers about this product and email them a video on youtube.com on this and they went to buyfrom amazon as soon as they got done watching the video.
  707. Have had 2 of these over last year. Bought first one brand new on auction website, worked great, wouldn't hold a charge more than a few minutes ... never ready when I wanted to use it. Thought that may be a fluke as I have a cordless Remington foil razor and Remington cordless beard trimmers that are excellent and hold charges great. I bought another packaged one, the newest model, unfortunately exact same results. If I forget to charge it for 1-2 hours before wanting it, I'm SOL. Great curved pattern for nice even cut, but with the lack of a good charge it frequently doesn't even hold a charge long enough to get 1 good cut.
  708. I used to have to set a shaver and tweak and tweak at my hair until finally getting it to look right. Now I just use this and set the setting to whatever height that I want (usually setting 2) and shave. Its fast and easy. I hardly need a mirror. Thank you, whoever took the time to think of, and develop this idea!
  709. I've had four of these. I have to replace it every year because the power system dies out. It was poorly designed, and is pretty predictable. First, the blue charge indicator light will go out, then the battery will work for less and less time, whenever you use it. Eventually, it'll start turning off the minute you place it on your head, and at that point, it is curtains. Remington had a great idea with this product, but to make it inexpensive they had to sacrifice on quality. It WILL break, however, consider how much money you spend on haircuts (especially when you keep your hair at a 2, like me) and the cost of this item is justified. I may have to get one every year, but it beats going to the barber shop. Word of advice, don't try and replace the battery pack. Once you take this piece of crap apart, it is impossible to reassemble.
  710. At first glance, this novel design seems to be a great solution for very short hair. But, there are more cons than there are pros. The round cutting surface doesn't always match the shape of my head everywhere, like the back and sides, so I don't get an even cut everywhere. The combs are very uncomfortable on the scalp. The setting that I really want is somewhere between the preset lengths. The motor does not have that nice high rev that beard trimmers have. It always sounds like its low on power. It's difficult to clean. You end up with hair all over the sink and counter. My opinion is don't waste your money on this item. Instead, get a quality hair or beard trimmer with a wide cutting head with a vacuum feature to capture the cut hair.
  711. I am thrilled with this product. I have been looking for something like this for sometime now. It's ideal for that short stubble look for hair and beard. What really makes this product is the contoured head. Cutting your hair is as simple as running a comb or brush thru it. If you want that look BUY THIS!
  712. I note in the fine print that this has been discontinued by the manufacturer. Perhaps that is because of battery issues. After 7 months, mine no longer holds a charge. It did an okay job from the start, but with noticeable \\"engine revving\\" at times, and did cut my hair almost as short as I would have liked. After a few months, I noticed that it seemed less powerful, but it still worked. Today, it started up loud and strong but immediately lost steam when I touched it to my head. My hair is very short at its longest, and I'm guessing this would have ceased working with longer hair even more quickly than it did for mine. I cut my hair once or twice a week, so this saved me a good deal of time and money compared to barber visits. But I'm moving on to another clipper.
  713. By far this is the best trimmer I have ever owned... when it works.<br /><br />I am now buying a third one. Seems they lose the ability to charge ~1 years time.
  714. This is a great product that has saved me a lot of money. It works better than I thought it wood. If your first use is on long hair don't even worry about it because it cuts hair in very small pieces. My dog loves it.
  715. The Short Cut clipper is a very useful and money saving device. This is my second purchase of the Short Cut. I am nearly bald, and crop my hair very short. A trip to the barber was always full price, and that was repeated about every 10 days. I spent quite a lot of money at the barber shop. Two years ago I bought my first short cut clipper, and I was surprised by its effectiveness, the only expense was the initial cost. The device is bidirectional, and cuts effectively whether sliding it front to back or the reverse. It works great for eye brows on the shortest two settings. The Short cut has a small extendable blade for close trimming of the hair in hard to reach areas. There is an adjustment for length,with a range from 1/8 to a little less than an inch. Perfect for me, but not for all. I recently discovered that the batteries are not replaceable, and should be removed and disposed of properly before discarding the Short cut when they will no longer hold a charge That is a is a small price to pay for nearly 100 hair cuts.
  716. I am a 76 year old senior --- I love the clippers --- I shave my face and head about once a month --- I have just ordered my fourth set --- the batteries give out ---
  717. If you already have buzzed hair and just want to keep it trimmed then this is the thing for you. However if you have longer hair and think this will buz it down for you it won't. Long hair just lays down flat and the trimmers go right over it taking off a little at a time. Took me about an hour to work down to a point where I had a nice even buzz cut.
  718. it was OK for the first few uses but then the battery just kept holding less of a charge. Got to use it about once a week for 3 months then it would charge at all.
  719. The Remington Short Cut Clipper is an excellent replacement for traditional clippers. The curved blade & 1/2 height knob adjustment make this clipper fast & easy to use. No forgetting to raise or lower the 'handle' on a standard clipper, just dial in the height you want & comb through your hair. My first unit lasted two years before the battery stopped charging, but at the cost of only 2 haircuts, it's a bargain.
  720. I have been using this product for about 6 years now and am on my third one. I like the stubble look on my head, and can go 2 days between cuts.<br /><br />The curve of the blades is what makes this cutter unique, and it fits my head pretty well. A goo stubble cut every 2 days takes about 10 minutes.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Easy to use<br />- Effective for stubble look<br />- First one I bought 5 years ago was $50+, so the price on Amazon is a bargain<br />- Quality seems to have improved over the years.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- You will probably only get 2 years out of it due to battery life issues. Aside from the environmental impact, for &#60;$35 it is well worth using for 2 years.<br />- If you want a very close bald shave, this device will not go that close to the scalp.<br />- Needs to be cleaned every week or 2 to keep the hair from clogging it up. Cutting longer hair, like body hair, will definitely clog it up and once that happens it is really not possible to open the unit up and unclog it.<br /><br />All in all, I have been happy with this product, I just wish it had a better battery that would last 3 or 4 years.

  737. Functionally, the short cut delivers on the simplicity of trimming your hair at home.<br /><br />The real problem, and the cause for the poor review, is that like many others, my clipper only held a charge the first time I used it. The second time I tried, it died halfway through. I hop in the shower and five minutes or so later I'm washing all those little hairs down my drain!<br />One piece of advice I would give to a new purchaser would be if you rinse them off in the shower, be sure to dry them well and oil the blades and run them for a few seconds every time. If you don't the blades will stick and it won't turn on. Other that issue these were a great find.
