  761. Truth be told? I ordered this for my cat. I admit it. But now I only use it on my head.<br /><br />This has got to be one of the most interesting hair clipper ideas I have ever seen. It's certainly quirky, but it works, and it works well.<br /><br />I have an Oster professional trimmer that I love, but there was one day at the end of the summer where I was in a hurry and didn't feel like unpacking it. I really needed a trim, so I took this Remington, which I had purchased, as I said, for my long-haired cat, and, having not used it on the cat yet, I tried it myself. I put on the plastic guide, set it on the \\"longest\\" hair setting, and went to town.<br /><br />And it actually did a really good job. Seriously.<br /><br />This is one of those products that you think to yourself, \\"what is this, the new version of the Flo-Bee?\\" and no one would blame you for thinking so. But I've used it on my goatee (or van-dyke, to be accurate) and it worked just fine. It has a sideburn trimmer on the side above the power button that does an amazingly good job. It's very accurate, solid, and I used it to do the close work on my beard with excellent results as well.<br /><br />This is a device that you could really use every day if you wanted a fresh trim. In a couple of minutes, you're done. Look, this isn't a salon-calibre haircut you're going to get from this, but if you or your kids like really short hair in the summertime, then you're going to save a fortune on barber fees with this in the bathroom drawer. And hours of barbershop time.<br /><br />Is it for everyone then? Not a chance. But this light weight, rechargable clipper will give good clean no-nonsense and yes, short haircuts that look good in no time, with just a few passes over your head, as if you were combing your hair.<br /><br />Or, you could buy it for your cat. I'm still considering trying it on her, but I like having it around just for me, and the cat keeps giving me strange looks whenever I consider it...
  762. I have read about this product in several places, and all gave it a thumbs-up. As I am not crazy about paying a barber $15 (plus tip) for a haircut, I decided to buy one through Amazon, as I could not find one in any of the local stores. So far, I have given myself two haircuts, the second being better than the first - due to experience, I guess. However, it won't style your hair, and you'd better like your hair short and without a part. You do need to read the instructions first. Only problem is that you can't do a very good job on trimming the back of your neck and around the ears as you can't see what you are doing very well, even with a mirror, so I had to enlist assistance from my wife in those areas using the pop-up clipper. She doesn't particularly like doing that, but it takes only a couple of minutes so she doesen't complain a lot. The product does pretty much what is claimed for it, and if you like a buzz cut, it works fine. In my case, it's already paid for itself.
  763. First things first - does the product work?<br /><br />Absolutely - as advertised. I used it just 3 days ago and I had no problem doing most of it by myself. I just needed a little help on the back and around the ears, but I probably could have done that with a little more creative mirror work. The charge held well and the cut is even and nice-looking.<br /><br />But..<br /><br />The entire process is time-consuming. It took me over an hour and a half from prep time through clean-up.<br /><br />Why so long?<br /><br />Well, this little thing creates a lot of mess with little bitty pieces of hair so I cut my hair in the garage so I had to move cars and such. I DO NOT recommend using this clipper in your house.<br /><br />All of those little hairs get caught up in the clipper so I had to stop frequently, remove the guard/comb and dump those hairs in the garbage can.<br /><br />I still needed someone else to help around the ears and the back of my head. If you were going for the lowest setting this may not be an issue.<br /><br />Sweeping up takes a while and you'll have to shower afterwards. I was shocked at how many little bits of hair came off in the shower. I had to clean the drain trap out more than a dozen times while showering afterwards.<br /><br />You'll have to decide for yourself if it is worth all of the hassle. Personally, I found that I would save time and hassle by going to my barber getting my traditional buzz cut, even with the driving time included.
  764. When ordering this item through Vine, I figured it was just another hair clipper. In fact, it's a hair clipper designed to cut in the back and on the sides, where \\"normal\\" clippers have a bit more problem. Although not what I expected, it's a great product - saves a lot of time and hassle and does its with a much-reduced likelihood of horrific accidents. I've managed to have my hair cut using just this and a decent pair of scissors on the top - by someone I might not have trusted otherwise! Some caveats, though: You could easily shave your head bare if you didn't pay attention to the instructions and what you're doing. So do read the manual before beginning - unless baldness is part of your look. Also, as many have mentioned, it takes what seems like a long time to fully charge. This didn't cause me a single problem, but I'd hate to be in the middle of cutting my third head of hair with it fully charged! So if you've got a bunch of kids' hair to cut, make sure it's been plugged in long enough to prevent some new form of mohawk.

I will not buy another one. I will go looking for a professional hair trimmer - a model used by hair stylists and not one marketed towards consumers.<br /><br />*******************************<br />I got tired of spending $25 for a haircut every 6-8 weeks for a really simple hair style. I went looking for hair clippers and came across this innovative product. I have used it for two haircuts so far and it has now more than paid for itself.<br /><br />Some cautions, though. The battery doesn't seem to hold its charge long, so make sure to charge it the night before using it. Cutting one's hair is not as quick and easy as the ads lead me to believe. I have to go over my head very thoroughly over and over and even then there are still a bunch of hairs here and there that get missed and have to be clipped with scissors. Takes me about half an hour to cut my hair.<br /><br />On the plus side, the different length settings are accurate and I can trim down to just the length I want every time. The product is comfortable<br />to hold and really easy to control. I am happy with this product and recommend it to any guy with a short haircut who wants to fire his barber or hairstylist. I can now cut my hair my way on my schedule for free.

Sadly you can't plug in the charging cord and continue cutting as my beard trimmer does. The battery will now only hold a charge for about one minute then wait 16 hours for another minute of use! I liked this unit at first but now it's just something else to throw away! $30 is a lot of money to me and if it's a lot to you don't waste it on this product.
  778. Super easy to use love the different height levels...Great price
  779. This clipper has been great. I have had one for a year and a half. In fact I am buying a second one because It suddenly wont charge after 18 months. (And I think it is because it took too many clunks from being thrown into the drawer after use. But up to that time it has worked flawlessly with one caveat. I was reluctant to purchase initially because of the people that said it lasted only a few weeks. What I discovered is that if it seems sluggish when I turn it on, I put a drop of oil on the blades and MAGICALLY It comes ALIVE just as if it was brand new ! For those that say the battery doesn't last, try a drop of oil on the blades and you will be shocked how well it works again with just a little lubrication. But give me a break ! for $40 dollars, its the best clipper I have ever used. It lasted much longer than I ever expected.

Negatives are there is no way to tell when its fully charged because the light is always blue, and the guard sizes are a little off a 1 is really a 0 and so on. You would think having the guard on would be a 1 but let me tell you its a 0, trust me.
  784. Because of the way I use this, it's perfect for me. I keep mine cut very short so I don't use any of the adapters, instead, if needed I cut it back as much as I can with scissors, then finish it off with this using only the bare blade without any adapters. this buzzes it down to a very close crew cut, like a short beard. and the contour shape of the long blades is perfect for this. however I think it would be challenging to get a decent medium trim with this trying to use the cut adapters. your hair type would have to be just right for it. but to just buzz it down very tight is really easy with this when you get the hang of it. doesn't take long, and the unit lasts for years. I'm going to get another one soon just to have it. I don't expect it to last forever but for the price, I've had mine over 3 years easily. I thnk it's slowing down a little as the battery nears the end of it's service life, but it still works fine. very durable and you can rinse it briefly, but don't submerge it I guess they say. it's well worth trying, glad I did.
  785. I bought one of these clippers about 3 years ago and have used it every weekend since then. It is finally slowly not wanting to take a charge but that is ok as it didn't just up and stop in the middle of a cut so pretty pleased about that. Anyway, I am buying another today. 3 years service for $29.00 to me is not great but the clipper is so easy to use it's worth it. I don't want to mess around with other styles as this one is made to cut with the curve of your head be it top or sides and makes an even cut perfectly simple and fast.

  788. The curved surface is a great idea, but there's no flex. So if portions of your head are shaped in a way that differs from the curvature of the cutting surface, then you're not going to get an even cut. Imagine shaving your face with a non-flexible razor blade that's curved to fit your chin and jaw line, then using it on something relatively flatter, like cheeks or neck. You'd get a close shave at the edges of the blade, but not in the middle.

The women on the phone said that I need to plug it in and let charge for 16 hours before use...!!!!! 16 hours..!!!! I can charge an electric car for a shorter amount of time than this. I charged it overnight, and when I tried this morning to repair the damage it lasted less than 10 seconds. After reading other reviews by other owners with similar problems I scrapped my plans to overnight another and opted for a more reliable model from another manufacturer. Wearing out is acceptable but catastrophic failure with half a trim is not!

  817. I have two thoughts on this item after purchase and use: [1] I did read the product description in any detail and thus I was disappointed that it was not a corded clipper. I am not fond of chargers after living with a cell-phone for awhile. [2] This product comes with two combs, a &#34;balding Combe&#34; and a &#34;regular comb.&#34; I use the latter and the big problem that I have with it, is that it clogs up with hair clippings of less than 1/8 inch. I had to keep using an old toothbrush to clear it several times. I am also concerned that oiling it from time-to-time presents somewhat of a problem because it isn't easy to remove other parts to get to the area that wants the oil.<br /><br />All-in-all, I found that the price more than pays for itself when one considers that in a large city like I live in, haircuts are expensive (inclusive of tips) at about $20.00. So, I am saving some money. But had I to do it all over again, I would have purchased a corded electric clipper with various size heads like the barbers have in their shops.

  830. This is the second one that I owned. The first one I bought in 2009 at best buy. It lasted until the end of 2012. The battery just would not hold a charge anymore. I ordered this one from Amazon and the clipper is still great. It cuts evenly and contours to my head. I like to keep my hair short. I have noticed that this clipper has a better battery so far. I have cut my hair about 7 times so far and it has yet to lose charge and stop working. The clipper comes with an attachment that shaves to the skin, a regular attachment, cleaning comb, small bottle of oil, charger and manual. Make sure you remove the attachment that shaves to the skin prior to first use and install the regular attachment. Cleaning the clipper is fast and easy. If you like to keep your hair short this is a great clipper. However, if you have medium to long thick hair this won't work well.   845. I would give this product four stars for the great job it did (note the use of past tense) on my head and beard, but it deserves just 2.5 stars for poor durability/design and below-standard ability to hold a charge between uses. I bought it in 2012 and for more than two years it did a great job, despite its inability to hold a charge. It's now on its last legs: the motor powering the shears is too slow to give a good cut and it has to be recharged after one or two minutes of use. Add to these negatives the facts that its plastic body (particularly the removable/adjustable shear guard) is very delicate and its less-than-ergonomic design make it uncomfortable to hold while in use. Now that it's almost useless, I discovered that I get a BETTER trim (head hair and beard) if I use the various shear-guard attachments on my wonderfully serviceable Wahl PEANUT plug-in clipper. I fine-tune the beard details with my reliable (10-plus years of service and counting) Remington PG-250 trimmer. In short, I won't be buying another SCC-100 to replace this dying swan.

  852. This device is a genius design. It really works nice. But unfortunately it has a little feel of cheap material to it. I wish they spent some more effort to make it a quality product. I would pay a lot more for this device only if it was made with better quality. Overall, it is not quality made and feels a bit flimsy in the hand. It cuts hair really short, more good for buzz cuts. The longest comb that comes with it, at its longest setting, cuts like a #3 at the barber shop. The rest are even shorter. But overall it does a good job and it is super easy to use. It pays for itself in 2 months.<br />Now the problems that need improvement are: The on/off switch is in an awkward place and easy to turn off in the middle of your work. It is located where you have to hold the handle, which makes it easy to accidentally turn on or off. They either have to move the switch to a different location or put a lock on the switch to prevent accidental activation. The exchange of the combs is a bit hard. The fit is not perfect and feels like cheaply made stuff that barely fit its parts. Cleaning the device is a bit of hassle, especially since you have to remove the comb, which is hard to put back in due to poor fit. I use compressed air (air in a can) to blow it and that makes it easier. The other surprising and silly thing is that it does not work when connected to electricity. So if you run out of battery in the middle of your haircut, you are going to be stuck with a bad hair day, because the darn thing takes almost 24 hours to recharge. :-)
  853. It's a fine trimmer/clipper, perfect for guys who want to crop their hair close or -- like me -- who are balding. A nice even cut all over.   857. Sometimes I think people expect too much from tools. If you buy a wood chisel it doesn't make you a professional wood carver. This does not make you a professional barber.<br /><br />Since it's a tool you have to learn to use it. If you expect to just open the box and giver yourself a perfect haircut you should not buy it or return it immediately. Just like any tool it takes time to learn to use it properly. This is especially true since your hair and hair style is not the same as mine. When I had a lot of hair it took several visits for a new barber to learn what I liked so expect to spend some time in trail and error.<br /><br />That said I'm balding on the crown and I like to keep my hair short. If you have long or shaggy hair this probably won't work well for you.<br /><br />Personally, I didn't have much luck the first time. My hair was about an 1-1.5 inches long and I did not do well trying to trim it down even a bit at a time with this. My suggestion would be to use regular clippers to get your hair close in length the first time then use these to finish the job and maintain your haircut. Once you get it right and learn to use it this clipper is 2 minutes of work a week to keep your haircut well maintained all the time. You might even want to get a fresh barber cut then try to maintain it after a week.<br /><br />The charge lasts for 3-4 cuts for me and that includes trimming my beard.<br /><br />I will state that you might want to use a beard trimmer for the detail work like sideburns, around the ears and the neckline etc. Take your time too; it's harder to do but you can gouge and get an uneven cut.

  866. I have quite short hair, I generally us the 1/8&#34; clipper attachments. This clipper really did not work for me, it left lines of different lengths and was pretty much a disaster. Might work better for a fuller head of hair.

  868. If you shave your head, after you use this I don't know how you could go back to a level clipper
  869. I will start by warning people, do not buy this item, the battery died on me, refusing a charge after only four weeks.<br /><br />If the battery had worked, I would give this five stars. I buzz my hair. This clipper cut my hair cleanly and quickly. It is cordless and easy. It is a fantastic clipper except for the fact that it does not work after about the sixth use.<br /><br />There were other warnings about the battery, and I wish I had followed their advice.
  870. I have used this item and I rather enjoyed it.<br />It was easy to use and got kind of a kick out of it, you know, fun.
  871. I did a lot of research and I am so happy to have found this trimmer. It comes with 2 attachments. The balding attachment goes to 0.6mm. I however take off the attachments and put the metal directly on my scalp and it gets much closer. It gets just as close at the trimmer attachment on my Norelco electric shaver. Sometimes its tricky to get close around the ear area and I end up cleaning it up with my trimmer from my electric shaver which takes only a few seconds. I use this about once every 3 days to keep my head nearly bald without having to go thru the trouble of shaving. Plus I like the stubble look better than the shaved look. If you want a trimmer to get nearly bald that is very quick and easy to use you need to get this.<br /><br />I now have changed to shaving my head. I still use this to trim body hair, arms and legs. This is a great tool, very happy with my purchase.
  872. I've had this for 2 years now, and I've used it weekly. It does a great job. I've been away from home for a few weeks and did not bring this clipper and so I have had to use a traditional clipper with the small straight edge. I hate it! I've been spoiled with this wireless, CURVED clipper. With this clipper, it have fewer &#34;missed&#34; spots, and I never cut my head or ears.<br />I have to charge it about every 4 cuts, and oil it at the same time. Great product, recommended it to anyone who shaves their head regularly.
  873. This was easy to use, great haircuts. I would recommend. The battery works really well as well even though other people have complained in prior reviews.
  874. This clipper is the best hair clipper my husband has ever used. I recommend it to everyone who likes short cuts.
  875. I use this to trim my chest, back, arms legs and privates. You can go from adjustable lengths, (privates, arms and legs) to bare skin on your back!!! It is rechargeable, cuts in both directions and very little need for 2nd or 3 rd passes. I have used clippers, 360 man groomers and even epillady and this one is the fastest and most efficient trimmer out there.<br /><br />I have never used it on my head, but I guess it would work. I have owned it for over a year now and use a little mineral oil on the blades once a month and still running strong!!!
  876. I use these clippers in between my regular haircuts, for quick touch ups. Easy to use and rechargeable...so no cords to fuss with while you are using them. I only wish they had a few more hair length settings. Then it would be 5 stars.
  877. This is my second short cut clipper and is a great product, much easier to use than the normal straight edge clipper
  878. I've had this clipper for about a month and have only used it twice. Prior to using this, I used standard Conair clippers for several years. The problem I had with the standard clippers was that it took me a long time to even up the back of my head. I thought the this Remington would cut down the time needed to do this.<br /><br />What I found with this Remington Clipper was that if you wanted a very close buzz cut, it works well for that. But if you want any length at all other than near balding, you will be disappointed. Using the variable attachment, regardless of setting, I find it difficult to produce an even cut. Even with the close cut, I still had to go over head a hundred or so times before I was satisfied, so the whole process is time-consuming for me.<br /><br />In addition to the time and cutting difficulties, the Remington makes a mess. It doesn't just cut hair, it mulches it, so you have slivers of hair everywhere. To remedy this, I use over the tub prior to showering. This is a good way to contain the hair. You also have to clean and lubricate the unit after each use.<br /><br />I know it sounds like I'm ripping the Remington, however I'm OK with the purchase. I've used it twice with a month in between uses, so it's already paid for itself. I like the close buzz cut and spending the time on the cut and clean-up only once a month is not so bad. In addition, I believe that I'll get better at using it. So some of the negative things that I mentioned, may not be so bad over time.
  879. This is a pretty remarkable product and it is a shame they can't give it a more trustworthy power supply. I've been using mine for about 4 months now and can see the substantial power loss after just a few minutes of use. Luckily, getting a quick short hair trim doesn't consume too much power, then it's back on the charger. Really is nice to not have to go the barber any more though.
  880. At my age and with the minimal hair that I have, this is a great product for the price. I use it every 1-2 weeks to trim back my hair and save $15 a pop by not going to the barber shop. After 2-3 uses, it's paid for itself and in the course of the year, I've saved a lot of money.<br /><br />This is the third unit I've owned over the last couple of years. While it is claimed to be waterproof, the first one I rinsed off after use and it shorted out after several months of use. I know because I took it apart and could see the corrosion. The second unit lasted about 2-3 years and I would brush it off after use. The only drawback with the product aside from the faulty claim to be waterproof is that the rechargeable batteries are difficult to remove for disposable and are not replaceable.

  901. Below is the review I left when I first received this product and charged for the first time.<br /><br />This is what I find after the third charge.<br /><br />What a load of rubbish. After the first charge it is not able to hold a charge at all all. After a twelve hour charge it held its charge for about five seconds (NO EXAGERATION) after a third charge, no change. I now class this as an expensive paperweight!!!! If I could raight this below a one star I would.<br /><br />This is the second one of these that I have bought. The first was bought here in Australia and the charger was for 240volt down to 4volt. I had it for about three and a half years before it packed up. It gave me the best result of any clipper I have purchased yet. I could not buy another of these in Australia, and thought they were no longer made, that is, until finding them quite by accident on Amazon.<br /><br />I purchased this thinking my old charger would do the trick of charging the new clippers. Much to my surprise, the old charger was not needed as the new charger automatically switches between 110-240volt and converts down to 5.6volts, which just left the issue of the plug. It is supplied with a USA/Canadian type \\"A\\", so all that was needed was a Australian/New Zealand type \\"I\\" plug converter for around $AUS20.<br /><br />Another reviewer noted that these were for frequent light use. I agree, kind of. What I tend to do, is, with my more conventional type of trimmer take off most of hair to be cut, then, with the \\"Short Cut Clipper\\" just give my head a light going over, kind of like a finishing coat of paint you might say. This has given me a very professional look while at the same time, extending the life of the \\"Short Cut Clipper\\".<br /><br />Very, Very, Pleased

  903. I love this trimmer. My Maine Coon cat thinks this is a neat brush. She walks back and forth in front of me. It's not too noisy. I had tried an animal trimmer and it also clogged and was not nearly as easy to clean.   907. I have had this for nearly two years now, and I'm ready to give it up.<br /><br />The trimmer is great for very short buzz cuts, but it's not necessarily the fastest, and I usually have to make multiple passes to trim everything. The shape is great and comfortable, and the design is good, except that I constantly hit the on/off button on accident while trimming.<br /><br />The battery life is more than adequate for a full trim. I often trim my facial hair and [ahem] other stuff after doing my head, and if I start while fully charged, I can always get everything done. Unfortunately, it doesn't give you much notice if the battery is low. The warning light comes on, and then it's dead about 30 seconds later. You can't trim while charging, and even charging overnight won't get you a full charge.<br /><br />The shaping tool dealie is a bit rough on soft skin, but it's nice that it is included.<br /><br />My trimmer has gotten sluggish. I usually have to turn it off and on a few times before I can get it going at full speed. I figured I would leave this review before shopping for something else. We had a good run, kiddo, but it's time to say goodbye.

  911. The Remington Short Cut Clipper is nothing more and nothing less. It's not versatile, and it will not provide you with the tools to try out new styles. However, it's not supposed to. It'll cut your hair a consistent short length with relatively little effort. You could consider it one of those \\"not necessary but nice to have when needed\\" type tools. Is it something I'd find myself using on a regular basis? Absolutely not, but that's just me. If you like your hair to stay consistently short, this might be just what you need.
  912. I received the Shortcut for Father's Day and it is the greatest gadget gift I have ever received from my kids. I clipped on the \\"balding comb\\" and went right to work. Absolutely perfect down to the nub. \\"balding comb\\" is slightly misleading--if you want to be bald, you're going have to use a razor, but, you won't have much to shave. If there is one thing that might be improved, it is the cut that you get on the sides of your head. The curved blades which make it so easy to cut most of your head actually work against you when you cut over the ears.   913. This clipper is AWESOME! My wife's been cutting my hair for 10 or more years now (with a Wahl clipper), so this allowed me to do it by myself. I use it at the shortest setting which is shorter than my regular clippers were ever able to go. It is so easy to use. Just remember the 2 most important things: 1) Hold it like a brush when you cut your hair, and 2) Go slowly! You will still be able to cut your hair in less than 10 minutes going slowly. It cuts very easily and evenly because it cuts in both directions. It also cleans-up easily. I just use a brush to remove the \\"clippings\\" after I remove the cutting guard. I now end up cutting my hair every week. I can't express how much I really like this clipper! Finally, something that allows me to cut my own hair and does it very easily. If you like to keep your hair short, this is the perfect clipper for you.
  914. This is a clipper & trimmer in one. The trimmer slides out from the top & both are controlled by the power button. It has a 40 min use on rechargeable battery built-in so it's cordless. It cannot run plugged in once it runs out (14-16 hours to charge). The settings are done by dial to pop up/down the plastic comb 1-4 for 1/8\\" - 1/4\\". Supposedly you can also rinse the blades. The instructions say to use short strokes & don't move it too quick or you'll feel a pulling sensation. If you rinse the unit, you must re-oil it w/the tiny bottle of oil they provided or just use the small brush they give.<br />I had one family member try this on his very short hair though only in the back since the hair on top is slightly more then an inch & he did not want to cut it that short as well. The result in the back fixed a bad job the barber did & look perfectly uniform. We used the trimmer to clean the hairline in the back for a very polished job.<br />For $30 he said he would buy this unit. Another family member had even longer hair of 2-3\\" so he only used the trimmer on the back of his head for the hairline & as a beard trimmer which he said worked well.<br />It is designed well, especially the cordless feature since you would probably be slapped in the head if it was plugged in. I did hit the power button while using it once, it seems an overly large size of a button. The trimmer slides forward & has a locking button as well.<br />I think this was designed very well, I just wish it had even longer cutting lengths even just up to 2\\" or even a full inch.
  915. Good clipper, works better and is more convenient than traditional clippers. For longer hair a pair of scissors is needed beforehand to trim everything down, basically works well only on and for short cuts. The sideburn trimmer is hand as well. If I had to come up with one fault its the curve head which is sometimes hard to use but other than that a very good product.
  916. The first thing that you should know about this clipper is that it's called the \\"Shortcut\\" for a reason, the reason being that it only works if you want a buzz cut with your scalp showing.<br /><br />The second thing is that you should read the instructions before using it. It comes with the \\"balding comb\\" attached, so if you decide to charge it and start clipping, you're going to end up with a buzz cut.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />1. It comes in an easy to open package that you won't need a chainsaw to open<br />2. It includes two combs, a cleaning brush, blade oil, a charging adapter and an instruction manual<br />3. It's compact and easy to hold<br />4. It doesn't come with a bunch of different sized cutter attachments, as it uses a 5 position zoom wheel to set the length of cut you need<br />5. It has a pop out trimmer for around the ears and neck area<br />6. It has a warning light to tell you when it should be recharged<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />1. It takes about 16 hours for a full charge<br />2. As mentioned above, it comes with the balding comb already attached, and unless you read the instructions first (or this review) you won't know that the adjustable hair length settings only work with the adjustable guide comb. If you need to trim longer hair, you MUST change the comb first.<br />3. It doesn't work well with the adjustable guide comb. It hardly looks as though it's doing any cutting at all, but in a very short time you'll find that the hair clogs up the comb, necessitating removing the comb and cleaning it out before continuing. (The comb is curved inwards at the top, with horizontal bars, and these trap the hair, clogging the blades)<br />4. It takes much too long to get the job done.<br />5. The pop out trimmer works, but is tough on tender skin.<br />6. The location of the \\"on\\" button makes it much too easy for accidental starting while popping out the trimmer or changing the combs.<br /><br />I wouldn't recommend this for anything longer than a buzz cut or complete hair removal. For longer hair that just needs a quick trim, there are better clippers available.<br /><br />For buzz cuts - 4 stars<br />For longer cuts - 1 star<br />Average - 2.5 stars<br /><br />Amanda Richards, August 7, 2008here are better clippers available. For buzz cuts - 4 stars For longer cuts - 1 star Average - 2.5 stars Amanda Richards, August 7, 2008
  917. Used it three times, absolutely no trouble-- although I have my wife check the back and sometimes finish up. I could probably get by with a hand mirror.   918. I was excited to get this product and figured I couldn't go wrong. Then I used it and had bad results. It didn't cut very evenly and it even cut me.
  919. I buy way too many \\"gadgets\\". Most of them sound like cool toys and usually end up at the bottom of a drawer or in the trash. Of the gadgets I've bought that I can't live without, regardless of the price I paid, are my GPS unit, phone headset, Tivo and a handful of others. The first time I saw the Remington ShortCut hair trimmer I didn't think twice about it and walked away. It is a gadget that's designed for a very limited and specialized target market ... those who like to have their hair cut very short and evenly across their entire head. It's also a gadget that has zero necessity, because there are all kinds of hair clippers on the market, and only a small percentage of people cut their own hair. So I thought the idea was silly. Then I started looking at my hair in the mirror and noticed that there are always some wayward strands that grow faster and make my haircut look less-than-fresh. And, to get away with the close-cropped look, it really has to be trimmed every few days to keep it even and orderly. That would get pretty spendy at a barber shop. What I've been doing until I discovered the Remington ShortCut is to use regular electric barber clippers with one of those cheesy plastic guides that is supposed to cut your hair at an even length. It is definitely not easy to use single-handedly and the length of my hair after clipping is always just a tiny bit too short. With low expectations I tried the ShortCut. My first impression is that it has a pretty good build quality. It comes pre-installed with the balding comb. CAUTION: if you don't want to look like an egg after your first trim, be sure to take the balding comb off and replace it with the adjustable comb! The adjustable comb has 5 preset stops ranging from about ¼\\" to about ½\\". What Remington doesn't say is that you can really set it to anywhere in between if you are careful not to press it too hard against your scalp (which you shouldn't do anyway). After charging the unit overnight I was anxious to try it and swiped it a few times casually over my head. I was impressed. With a few simple motions, the same as using a hairbrush, the job was done and my hair was very neatly trimmed, with no pesky strands of longer-than-usual hairs poking out. A few minutes every few days is all it takes to have your hair perfectly trimmed 24/7. In my judgment, that is what make a product a necessity rather than a gadget, and makes it worth whatever price you pay. Except the price for the ShortCut is dirt cheap. This is one of the most highly recommended items I've reviewed and earns a solid 5 stars. For maybe 95% of people, they would have no need for the ShortCut, but for me and guys like the new U.S. president it is a total winner.ht I was anxious to try it and swiped it a few times casually over my head. I was impressed. With a few simple motions, the same as using a hairbrush, the job was done and my hair was very neatly trimmed, with no pesky strands of longer-than-usual hairs poking out. A few minutes every few days is all it takes to have your hair perfectly trimmed 24/7. In my judgment, that is what make a product a necessity rather than a gadget, and makes it worth whatever price you pay. Except the price for the ShortCut is dirt cheap. This is one of the most highly recommended items I've reviewed and earns a solid 5 stars. For maybe 95% of people, they would have no need for the ShortCut, but for me and guys like the new U.S. president it is a total winner.
  920. I had been interested in buying this product before I even new exactly what is was that I wanted to buy. After some research online, I discovered the Remington Clipper. I've only used it a few times and am very satisfied. One more month without going to the barber and I will have recouped my expenses. While the &#34;negative&#34; reviews may come to pass, such as the battery, until then I consider it well worth $30.<br /><br />Tip - set the clipper to 1 (lowest/shortest setting) to cut the hair on your neck.
  921. This thing saved me a ton of money- I generally like the design. The flaws are a medium quality battery which apparently works for 6 months of use and then doesn't charge enough (haven't had this happen yet). I wish this thing would also work while plugged into the charger cable, so you could use it when the battery dies. Other than that, I have no complaints. I clipped my hair to a #4 length- I had longer hair to begin with. Ideally this is used for short hair to maintain it. It is not particularly powerful, so if your hair is grown out like mine was, it will take quite a few back and fourths to get rid of the hair- not to mention tapping out the clipper when it gets clogged up every 5 or so passes. However.... This is still a great deal, and already saved me money. you still need a mirror set to get the back line right on your head, and I brought in my girlfriend to touch up some spots on the back and by my ears. In any case, if this thing even lasts 4 hair cuts, I am way in the green. My hair cut came out as good as super cuts etc. and I can maintain it at this length now. 5 stars when they come out with plug-in-able version. You will need a full charge to get through a tougher hair cut. Very easy to adjust lengths, and comes with two guards (one is like a #.5-2.5, ad the other is up to a #4) The guards clip in and out easy, and this thing is light and feels like you are brushing your hair. Overall a good do for the short hair-types.

  930. Clips just the way I need
  931. The product works great and for balding hair cuts, I use the device without the plastic guard.<br /><br />I read online before buying that product to remember to drain the battery after 1 or 2 hair cuts (i.e. keep it running until the battery dies)- only then should you recharge for a full 24 hours. Then it is as good as new for 1 or 2 more hair cuts.<br /><br />REMEMBER: it is all strategy. Cut your hair but remember to DRAIN the battery before performing a 24 hour re-charge.
  932. Let some one cut ur hair with thing or else.
  933. Let me start by addressing the elephant in the room, the battery. I was very hesitant to buy the Remington Short Cut because of the large number of negative reviews about the battery. I'm glad I decided to buy it anyway. My experience with the battery so far has not been a negative one. The first time I charged the Short Cut I left it plugged in overnight. When the unit is charged the blue light will go out. I get about two 10-12 minute trims on a single charge with about two weeks between trims, so I end up charging the Short Cut about once a month. I always charge it the day before I need to use it and never after the battery is run down after performing a cut. While I can't speak about the longevity of the battery, I can say that I am happy that I don't need to charge the Short Cut every time I use it. I think the longer you go between charges may extend the overall life of the battery as well. Update: I used my Short Cut this morning (7/5/15) and decided I would update my Amazon review. To my surprise I checked my purchase history and I purchased my Short Cut on 6/27/13 and it is still going strong, and I mean strong. I typically use it 2-3 time as month and charge it about every 2 weeks. I think the key to longer battery life is cleanliness. I thoroughly clean and oil the blades each use. At first I wasn't oiling the blades after each use but I noticed an audible difference in the sound after oiling. It sounds smoother and less worked when oiled regularly. This thing has saved me well over $200 and I would definitely buy another one once the battery on the one I own now dies. Right now it is not showing any sign of it. OK, on to the rest of my review. The very first time I cut my hair with the Short Cut I was very nervous. I have always had my hair cut by someone else my entire life so the thought of doing it myself was rather daunting the first time. However, the product's box is correct: You can't mess this up! You literally use the Short Cut like a comb and it does all the work for you. The whole process is pretty messy so you better have a towel wrapped around your neck. I quickly learned the best place to cut my hair is in the shower before taking a shower. When I'm done I clean the Short Cut and after taking a shower I don't have the irritating feeling of hair on my neck and shoulders. The end result is a nice even short cut hair cut. A few other things about the Short Cut. It comes with two guards, oil, and a cleaning brush. The first time I plugged it in to charge it the blue light came on and when I checked it the next morning (less than 10 hours later) the blue light was out. Initially I thought something was wrong but this is a normal indication. The Short Cut comes with two guards. One guard is primarily for bald cuts while the other guard lets you choose an adjustable length cut be turning a wheel on the Short Cut which adjusts the guard up and down. A word of caution: When changing the guard or removing the guard to clean the Short Cut, adjust the guard up to the highest setting and gently remove the guard. The guards are keyed which make putting it back on a breeze. Again, use the highest setting when removing or changing the guard. There are a few things I don't like about the Short Cut. First, the Short Cut does not come with any kind of storage bag, but I did find that everything fits nicely into a gallon zip lock bag. The Short Cut has a built in pop out trimmer but it does not work very well. Honestly, it was a big let down the first time I tried to use it to trim my sideburns and around my ears. It just doesn't really feel like it is cutting anything. This is the main reason I give it 4 instead of 5 stars. Overall, I would highly recommend the Short Cut for anyone who likes a short buzz cut. For years and years I paid on average $10-12 for a buzz cut about once a month. With the Short Cut I am able to maintain my short cut by using it about three times a month. I cannot tell the differencebetween a professional $10-12 cut and the Short Cut cut. The $29.99 I paid for the Short Cut has already paid for itself. The Short Cut literally feels like you are brushing your hair, it's that easy. No matter what direction you are brushing, the Short Cut is cutting your hair. The more you use the Short Cut the more comfortable it feels cutting your own hair. If you like your hair short and looking for a way to maintain a good looking hair cut and save money to boot, the Short Cut is worth a look. You really can't mess this up!
  934. Why would anyone go to the barber when this is so inexpensive. In two hair cuts, this pays for itself. Actually, its great for all over hair. The unit is curved to shape your head as well as &#34;other&#34; body parts. We have three at home and this was the cheapest one we have found so far.<br />The charge last a very long time, it it easy to clean and does not pull hair out while shaving. VERY happy with product and service.

It blends great and you will have a hard time screwing it up since it is contoured to the shape of your head. Best clipper design on the market in my opinion. I usually let my 10 yr old daughter cut my hair since she gets a kick out of it, and results are as good as if I just walked out of the barber shop. I have to cut my hair about once a week to keep the length consistent, but since it literally takes me 5 minutes, it is no problems. Highly endorsed!

  955. This unit does not have enough power, unless you already have hair that is 1/4 inch in length. And the power varies while it is running through your hair, sometimes creating divots. With a Wahl unit that I purchased recently it is one slow pass and you are done, and has many more length options and more sturdy ones at that. The power of the Wahl is what you might expect at a salon/barber shop. Pass on this one and get a Wahl or something similar.

  964. I had fairly short hair when I first went to use this on myself but I was still cutting off 1/2\\" worth of hair. I noticed right away that the trimmer blade is straight up and down rather then having two cutting surfaces going in opposite directions. Why is this an issue? This means that when you go to cut your hair it cuts off millions of tiny little pieces of your hair and leaves quite a mess. I had been cutting my own hair with a regular Wahl clipper but it was tricky and I had to wait until my hair was fairly long in order to cut it easily. This is the exact opposite of this Remington clipper. The reason I ultimately like this device is that once your hair is short this clipper is great at keeping it short. I simply run this clipper over my head at the end of every week and it does a great job of keeping my head short and neat. The trick with this device is to cut your hair more frequently to maintain your style. If you always wait for your hair to get somewhat long and then try to use this clipper, it will probably take longer and create a bigger mess then if you had tried doing it with traditional clippers. If you want to maintain a short hair style (1/4\\" or so) this works well for me.

The blades are exposed like a close trimmer, so you just run it along your neck and it does a nice job. Very efficient and fast. It can't get really close to your ears because of the size of the trimmer guide, so it helps to have another smaller head trimmer for close work around them.<br /><br />Works pretty well overall though, assuming you like a short and uniform haircut.   984. My son has always had very long hair, between ear length to shoulder length and I have zillions of photos of him running, playing, jumping, with his hair whipping around. A little athletic hippy he is.<br /><br />Then all of a sudden he wants it cut short. He's six, so he should be able to decide for himself, but I asked him several times if he was sure and he said he was.<br /><br />&#34;Sometimes, when I'm eating ice cream I get hair in my mouth.&#34;<br /><br />&#34;But are you sure?&#34;<br /><br />&#34;All my friends have short hair.&#34;<br /><br />&#34;Okay, let's do it.&#34; I said.<br /><br />And that's where this baby, the Remington Short Cut Clipper comes in.<br /><br />Obviously I couldn't take the machine straight to his head, shore his golden locks the way a sheepherder does sheep, so I got out my scissors and cut his hair, leaving about an inch all the way around. Pretty awful looking. Then I trimmed it with the highest setting and that was it.<br /><br />I have to say, I'm not used to his hair looking like that, but he loves it.   985. I stand by this product, as it has saved me countless dollars per use.<br /><br />This is the second one I've bought(first time through Amazon) in the past since 2008 or so if i recall. The first one couldn't hold the charge anymore, due to what I believe was poor storage management. As I would usually leave it plugged in for recharge in the bathroom where there's constant moisture and leave it alone till I'm ready to use it again in 3 weeks or so.<br /><br />A little back story why I've bought this...Like many men, I'm starting to gradually lose hair. And going to the barber has become, embarrassing sort of speak. With this, I've been able to save the thought of believing that other people even bother to think what I look like, but it's just that much more comforting knowing you don't have to doubt yourself. A typical trip to the barber will run me around $15 + tip, and that at least saved me $1,000 over the years.<br /><br />Now on to how I use this. There's pretty much only 2 hair styles a person using this product can do by themselves. 1 - all around even cut or 2 - cut the sides short and leave the top longer with some scissors for room to style. I will have to say, the first time using these clippers, I was inexperienced and it looked hideous. But with practice comes perfection. No one is perfect their first time so they might mark it off as a mistake. But once you get a routine down, in 10 minutes you'll have a style you're accustomed to.<br /><br />When I cut my hair, I lean over the tub. Make sure to use the default comb.<br />1. Have the clippers on setting 2.<br />2. Start with the back and go back and forth until the hair is clean. Some tapping on the clipper may be required to remove the hair depending on how long your hair is.<br />3. After that I proceed with the sides.<br />4. Once that's done, setting 1.5 on the back and work my way up from the bottom to maybe earlobe height.<br />Set it to 1 and cover half way of the 1.5 setting.<br />5.Set it to 3 and cut the rim between the sides and top.<br />6. Depending what you want, it's your choice to go from there. But I highly suggest using the same comb filter on 4 setting and just clip it through to see how it looks on you.<br />7. Use the slider to clip the hair around your ears that the normal clipper couldn't get to.<br /><br />And that's it!
  986. This is the second time I've used it ,after I got more used to it, things went very well. Hair was longer the first time , had to brush it out three times, easy to do.   989. I'm a \\"bald guy\\", and got tired of waiting in line at a barber or other place for a hair cut. This product works great, however the battery life is short when using. It only takes me about 3-4 minutes to buzz down my hair, but near the end is sounds like the battery is nearly dying. It does charge up quickly, ready for the next use. I don't mind re-charging between each use, but I'm wondering over time if the battery will not hold a charge. You cannot use it while it's plugged in (which is good, to keep fools form using near water!), but if the battery life goes dead during use at some point, this will not be good. It does seem to re-charge quickly.
  990. I like it but with reservations. I've bought this Remington twice now. The first one I bought crapped out after a year of use. I wear my hair at the lowest setting. It does the job for about 35 haircuts or so, but then seems to clog up no matter how often you try to clean it. The best results come if you use it every other day or every third day so that it isn't dealing with a lot of hair to cut. No matter what anyone says ... I also DO NOT advise letting water get anywhere near it. To my mind, no company has really come up with a convenient product yet that will easily and reliably keep your hair short and last long enough to be a real bargain. The Remington Short Cut Clipper is as close as you can get to this standard... but still not worthy of raving about...
  991. I've seen many of the same reviews for this product. I've been using this device for years, and it works great. But the battery they chose for this device is pretty bad. As you cut your hair, it will speed up and slow down for no reason. It also doesn't always hold a very long charge, so I keep it plugged in all the time. Unfortunately, for some reason they designed the device not to work while plugged in. It's battery or nothing.<br /><br />On the flip side, it does a great job when it's working. I cut my hair once a week. If you get lucky and receive one that lasts a year or so, you're paying $30 for 75 haircuts or so. It's still MUCH cheaper than having someone else do it.<br /><br />I just purchased my third device, and it was delivered dead, unable to hold a charge. I'm sending it back in exchange for another to see if I can get lucky again. If you get one that works, you'll love it.
  992. Received 3 units, the 1st one would not charge, the 2nd unit didn't charge up and operate ether, the 3rd unit did charge up and is operating ok. The hair cut was quick and looked very good. I think that only one working out of 3 isn't a very good average.

But I love it so much that I always keep two charged up, ready for one to run out -- or FAIL.   1068. Works great and I love it. I read all the reviews and am aware that Remington used the cheapest rechargeable batteries available. Phillips Norelco razors are similar. The cheaper the razor the cheaper the batteries, the longer the charging time. If you want this product to last, you only recharge it when necessary and never leave it plugged in. The batteries will develop a memory and appear to be dead. What I don't understand is why Remington uses rechargeable at all. Just fit it with a battery holder and let the purchaser put his own batteries in it. That way the product would last forever. Then again, if this product only lasted one year, 12 haircuts would cost you $2.67 each. Buy a new one every January.

  1077. The first time I used this, I did an excellent job of scalping myself. Problem: Used the super-short comb. Now, cutting my hair is a breeze. There is a wheel to set the length of hair. The regular comb won't let you scalp yourself. I finish up around the back, over the ears and sideburns by turning the wheel and making the cut a little shorter. Be methodical, slow down, enjoy the scalp massage, and save yourself $20 and a trip to the hair stylist.<br /><br />This utilizes a single blade cutting vertically. As you brush back and forth, the hair is trimmed to the depth you set. There are two combs. One for cutting right down to the scalp, the other for a uniform depth. I think the max length hair is about 1/2 inch. Min is probably about 1/8 inch. There is a wheel to set the depth. A brush to clean the blade, and oil to keep it lubricated.<br /><br />You need this if you like your hair shorter. Terrific product.

  1079. As a balding male who often makes trips to the barber to get his head buzzed, I thought this would be a good way to save a few bucks. I'm at the stage where I need to shave my head probably every 2-3 weeks in order to maintain a nice sleek look, so you can guess how costly that would become over a year!<br /><br />The product itself seemed simple enough to use. It's shaped like a comb and everyone has combed their hair at one point or another! Put both ideas together and it should be a breeze, right?! Well kind of.<br /><br />1) The biggest issue with this device is the battery. After the initial use, it seems to die down really quickly no matter how long you charge it for.<br /><br />2) The comb design sounded neat but it's really quite a disaster. I've notice that shaving the sides or the back of my head to be extremely difficult. Assuming your head is shaped like a volleyball, the sides of your head are slightly less curved then the top. This means that there is a slight gap between both edges of the blade when your cutting. Maybe it's just my head but I've struggled mightly with trimming the sides and back with this device.<br /><br />Simply put, I used it twice and it's sat in the cupboard since. If you want to buy something that's effective, I suggest a standard clipper like you find it most barber shops. I'd also suggest buying a device that requires a power cord as oppose to battery. It may be a bit of a nuisance at times, but I'll take good old reliable over a draining batter any day.
  1080. EDIT: It wasn't the battery. I did some research after writing this review, and saw that if you don't clean and oil the blades, regularly, it gets bogged down on debris. So I cleaned and oiled the blades... and it was resurrected! Working as good now as the day I bought it, batteries and all. Perhaps eve a bit better as the blades are self sharpening. If you're using it on your scalp, don't be overzealous around any moles that might have some height to them. You'll give them a good scrape. Other than that, still fantastic. Changing it to four and a half stars - I'd go 5 if it were a little less maintenance.<br /><br />ORIGINAL: When adequately powered, this works great. I loved it, at first. The problem is that the device can only run off the battery* and the battery went south almost immediately. Within a couple months it would still be weak directly after charging and the motor would wind down to nothing before I could trim my entire beard. It's currently unusable. My beard grows faster than this thing can trim it.<br /><br />(*plugging it in the power cord puts it in charge mode and shuts off the motor)

  1084. Bought my first one of these just over three years ago but eventually the batter became weak and it was not worth my time or money to replace since it is a sealed unit and not intended to be replaced.<br /><br />If you are used to a plug in electric clipper you will be dissapointed until you use this a few times and get used to how it works. I use this exclusively for my own haircuts now and leave the plug in Brawn in the drawer. When cutting it is important not to take too much at once and to shake out the comb/guard often so that it does not clog and bog the unit down. Because this is waterproof I am able to cut my hair every 2-3 weeks in the shower and there is no major cleanup. Just rinse everything down the drain and rinse the unit off under the faucet. Just give it a good oil coat after or before use and always charge before use and this unit will work well for you. Be sure to give it a few charge/drain-by-using cycles before giving up on it.<br /><br />If I could change anything on it, I would include the cut length for both guards - unit only includes cut length for the short guard. Also, I would make the batteries replaceable. I took my old unit apart and because the batteries are sealed and soldered in place it isnt worth replacing them when they die after 3 years.

  1089. So simple. So fast. This really simplifies life. And if the rechargeable batteries don't last as many reviewers claim, there are better models for a bit more.<br /><br />I will qualify this review by stating that I've only used it at the closest setting (1 = 1/8\\"). On that setting it works really well.<br /><br />Love it.<br /><br />I'm adding this after owning and using this product for approximately 5 months.<br />I have had zero battery issues. I bought 2 so that I can let the battery run out completely before charging it, which should help tremendously with battery life.<br /><br />It can't be used when the charger is plugged in, so I just grab the other one and let the dead one charge fully until the blue charge light turns on.<br /><br />I've recommended this product to many, most of whom have used regular barber clippers for years, and they all love it.<br /><br />Mark<br />HB, Ca.
  1090. Easiest way to cut your own hair I have ever experienced.
  1091. Works great...before the batteries die. I am on the seventh one of these, because the batteries only last about 6-12 months for me cutting my hair every 1-2 weeks. However, it is a great concept. I actually buy mine from another company that are more expensive initially, but have a lifetime guarantee. So when the battery quits, I send the clippers back and they send me a new one. I am only out the price of the shipping each time. It would also be nice if they would make the clippers, so they would run plugged in with the cord, but they only run unplugged with the battery. Having watched several YouTube videos, I am now also going to try the Philips DIY model and post a review comparing the two clippers.

  1103. Have used this since early December, it works well to cut hair, you need to be very careful and cautious with the settings and clippers at first. Less is more initially. Requires several stop and clearing out the teeth before going again as well as well oil to keep the blades in tip top shape. I would recommend using a mirror to make sure you can attain an even cut on the areas you can't see. I have made my share of hair mistakes with this and would say go slow and have a pail/ brush/broom ready for cleanup. Would recommend cleaning frequently it does the trick. Update April 15': Purchased this item in December of 2013 and still running strongly. Religiously clean the blades and use a Q-tip inside the unit as well as oil the blades. I never use the attached trimmer I find it too difficult and rigid to use. I would recommend a separate one for around the ears/sideburns/neck area. As far as cutting pretty easy to adjust and maintain. Haven't gone for a haircut in a long while and this unit has paid for itself time and time again.

  1117. I've been using this product for a few weeks now and I love it! I like keeping my hair short and it works great for that--just like the name says. It is super easy to use--just run it back and forth over your head like a comb and this little gadget does the rest. I used to have trouble trimming my hair line in the back with a clipper because I couldn't see what I was doing. No worries with this device; I just put it on the shortest setting and sweep it in a twisting motion from the base of my neck up to the hairline and out. I get a perfect cut every time.<br />With that said, there are a few things I've learned about this product.<br />The instructions say you can leave the unit plugged in without worrying about overcharging it. I recommend leaving it plugged in. The charge doesn't last long enough for me to do two haircuts (I learned the hard way) so it's best to have a full charge each time.<br />The unit cannot be run on AC power. Plugging in the charging cord locks the power button so it cannot be turned on while charging.<br />The numbers on the adjustment wheel are very small and I have to wear my readers to see them.<br />This thing doesn't cut off a length of hair like a clipper does. Rather it &#34;nibbles&#34; at your hair resulting in a lot of &#34;hair dust&#34; that can clog the cutting head rather quickly. Every few strokes I have to shake the hair out of the plastic length guide. The instructions say you can rinse it clean under running water. But I'm old school and haven't yet dared put this electric device in water.<br />Because of that cutting action you will want to use this product frequently--once a week or once every two weeks. If you try to cut too much hair with it (say 1/4 inch or more) it will very quickly get bogged down.<br />I haven't tried the &#34;balding&#34; attachment that comes with it. Maybe I'll get a friend to try that.<br />The build feels OK. Not great, not bad. Sometimes I feel like I'm going to break the plastic length guide when I remove it for cleaning. I'm curious to see how the whole things stand up to frequent use.
  1118. I hope this last as long as the razor I own. (10 years!)
  1119. This is a fantastic machine. It cut my hair precisely the very first time I used it. I cut my hair every three days or so and every time I use the Clipper I am delighted by the results. I will never go back to a salon for haircuts (thereby saving a fortune over time - price of haircut, tip, gas to drive to the salon and time spent). If you read the brief instruction book that comes with the Clipper, you won't get balded like some of these reviewers did (because they didn't read the instructions). The Clipper comes with the balding comb affixed; so if you don't want balding, you must change the comb before proceeding. Not a big deal at all; some people make everything a big deal because they are in a hurry. This Remington is a quality Clipper, easy to use and does EXACTLY what Remington says it will do. I love it ! No complaints whatsoever.

Then I run it over my cheeks and chin, moving it to different angles so that it does not cut too deep on certain areas. Bingo, I am done in a few minutes and my cut is even and very, very short!<br /><br />Leave it connected to the charger and you will be ready to cut always.   1126. I am on my 2nd Remiington Short Cut clipper. The first one died in less than a year. The charging light went off and the clipper quit working. I contacted Remington and they shipped out a new one and I sent the dead one back. Shipping both ways was free. After less than a year same thing happened, the charging light went off and the clipper quit working again. I read a few reviews here on Amazon and found someone had opened up the unit and found it caked with oil and hair cuttings. He said once he cleaned it out it ran like new [except I think it was ruined from ripping open the casing].<br /><br />With nothing to loose I figured if grease and clippings could get in they can get out without tearing upon the unit. I ran the clippers under hot water for a few minutes at an angle not submersing the whole unit. I shook it out and when I turned it on it ran great. I am not sure if this is a real fix or if I just got lucky but I was able to cut my hair and charge it so I'll keep cleaning it this way and see what happens.<br /><br />Bottom line is the design could be better to keep gunk from getting inside. For me it does a good job on my short hair and it's easy to use. If all it takes is to run it under hot water once a month than it's a keeper.

  1131. I like to keep my hair short and have been using regular clippers to cut it, But these clippers are fantastic, it's just like combing your hair to cut it. They are shaped to your head, which is much more useful to use than regular clippers with a flat blade, also they collect most of the hair they cut, I was expecting hair all over the place like my old clippers but was suprised to see they were clean and easy to use.   1132. I ended up buying this clipper directly from Remington because of the battery complaints noted on Amazon. Remington assured me if I bought their latest model, the batteries would be fine.<br />So far I've given myself three haircuts with one battery charge. One cut was pretty serious hair removal and two were just touch-ups.<br />I'm quite happy except for these small issues.<br />If you tap the unit on your hand to knock some hair out of it, be sure to check the setting as a slight amount of tapping will cause a setting change. I was giving myself a \\"two\\" and tapped it on my hand. The stetting changed and I ended giving myself a 1 1/2.<br />Also... It's curved, so it requires some creativity to get the same length on the flatter sides of your head, but it works well with a few extra passes in different directions.<br />I like it so far.
  1133. The Remington clipper worked OK for a few months, and then charging/battery problems began. First, the blue charging light did not come on when I plugged it in, but the clipper still worked...for a while, then it wouldn't hold a charge at all. You think since it has a charger, it would still work. Oh no! The clever engineers behind this clipper designed it so it doesn't to not work when it is plugged in. What a stupid concept. That was a surprise to me when I bought it, so be aware of that limitation. Thus, what I have now has the functionality of a paperweight.<br />I just bought a Philips Norelco QC5530 and it is worlds better - in design, flexibility of use, and the quality of the construction (lithium battery and it operates in both cordless and corded mode). And its' only 5 bucks more at Amazon. [[ASIN:B004QWVY8A Philips Norelco QC5530 Do-It-Yourself Hair Clipper]] Take my word on it and don't waste your money on this Remington clipper..... unless you need a paperweight
